From tim1 at timduru.org  Tue Sep 26 03:50:42 2006
From: tim1 at timduru.org (tim1 at timduru.org)
Date: Tue, 26 Sep 2006 07:50:42 +0000 (GMT)
Subject: FL: The Original Fursuit Database - http://www.fur-suit.org/
In-Reply-To: <005601c6e11c$34474e20$0a01a8c0@growl>
References: <005601c6e11c$34474e20$0a01a8c0@growl>
Message-ID: <20060926065332.H92584@j3.timduru.org>



ok, well since it's posted here,
I might as well add some more infos and things that might be of interest
for this list.  :)

As far as I know this list is mostly about performance and construction
and fursuits as piece of art. :)


So the Fursuit Database, can help all that at a certain level :)

It'll keep fursuits data and history, so that the suits and infos are not
'lost' for the future, kinda like the fursuit archive, but not only on a
photo level, it has all the infos :)

I'll just list a few examples that might be of interest here, but
possibilities are endless with the combined criterias :)
Keep in mind that even if it's a fully functionnal "basic version",
it's far from beeing finished, and there are many features and things
coming still :)


**Construction**

From bogus@does.not.exist.com  Fri Sep 15 09:51:10 2006
From: bogus@does.not.exist.com ()
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 2006 13:51:10 -0000
Subject: No subject
Message-ID: <mailman.1.1159257295.5691.fursuit-list@lists.fursuit.org>

I tried to write the search engine with that part in mind too.
There are many criterias that can be usefull for that.

For example if you are making your own fursuit, let's say a fox , and are
looking for
fox fursuits for reference, based on mesh heads, that are mostly
reaslistic and have
digitigrade legs ?

Well easy , just select all those criterias on the search page and hit
search, you'll then get the list of suits matching these criterias. :)

You can do so with many other criterias pertaining to construction :)
3D eyes, head types, suit types, etc..
I'll reorganise the criterias better as they are growing. ;)

**Buying**
You're going to buy a suit of a certain species, but not sure who to
commission ?
well just search for all suits of that species, and then see which builder
fits more what you are looking for , then just go to their website for
more infos once you've choosen :)



**Performance**
suiters have the hability to list their suits as 'available for
performing'

So you can also search for those available for performing :)
let's say that for a particular event, you are looking for wolf costumes,
in California, but which are 75% toony or more as to not scare childrens ?
Well , again just fill in all those criterias and you'll get the results

**Finding a suit**
you've seen a suit at a convention, you know it's a wolf,  and would like
to contact the owner
/ builder, but are unsure who it was  ?
well search all suits who attended that convention and are a wolf, fill in
any other criteria to pin point more, or just list :)

**Suiters**
well it's a good place to keep your suit datas and history in the DB, so
that you can point others to the infos, and keep track of the suit history
:)



Well I'm not going to list all , but possibilities are endless,
and if you think there's something missing or  a major feature missing
don't hesitate to contact me to give your suggestions :)

I need to take a small break from all the coding I had in the past few
months on the site,
but features will be added as my time permit.
And the 2nd more eye candy and dynamic interface will be coming too
(Yakeo will be working on the design and I'll do the rest  )

Well thanks for reading,
and unless it's remarks pertaining to the subject of this list,
better take it on the site's LJ or in private emails as to not spam the
list.
Thanks :)


On Mon, 25 Sep 2006, Growl wrote:

This is a user friendly and fully searchable site created to capture the best representation of  your fursuits for future posterity.
>
> -Growl

history of my suit creation as he has gone throught a few re-hashes - esp in

Growl,

I went looking around for the entries I made for Ashes and for Rocky and I 
thought I uploaded them to Fur-suit.org when it was first opened.

Now it seems there's no record of either of the two fursuits I enrolled in 
the site.  Did the site lose information when it was updated to the new 
search engine or is there a third fursuit database out there that I can no 
longer find?

Thanks for looking into this.

Swift Fox

           Safety the Firefighting Fox

>> There are many criterias that can be usefull for
>> that.
>>
>> For example if you are making your own fursuit,
>> let's say a fox , and are
>> looking for
>> fox fursuits for reference, based on mesh heads,
>> that are mostly
>> reaslistic and have
>> digitigrade legs ?
>>
>> Well easy , just select all those criterias on the
>> search page and hit
>> search, you'll then get the list of suits matching
>> these criterias. :)
>>
>> You can do so with many other criterias pertaining
>> to construction :)
>> 3D eyes, head types, suit types, etc..
>> I'll reorganise the criterias better as they are
>> growing. ;)
>>
>> **Buying**
>> You're going to buy a suit of a certain species, but
>> not sure who to
>> commission ?
>> well just search for all suits of that species, and
>> then see which builder
>> fits more what you are looking for , then just go to
>> their website for
>> more infos once you've choosen :)
>>
>>
>>
>> **Performance**
>> suiters have the hability to list their suits as
>> 'available for
>> performing'
>>
>> So you can also search for those available for
>> performing :)
>> let's say that for a particular event, you are
>> looking for wolf costumes,
>> in California, but which are 75% toony or more as to
>> not scare childrens ?
>> Well , again just fill in all those criterias and
>> you'll get the results
>>
>> **Finding a suit**
>> you've seen a suit at a convention, you know it's a
>> wolf,  and would like
>> to contact the owner
>> / builder, but are unsure who it was  ?
>> well search all suits who attended that convention
>> and are a wolf, fill in
>> any other criteria to pin point more, or just list
>> :)
>>
>> **Suiters**
>> well it's a good place to keep your suit datas and
>> history in the DB, so
>> that you can point others to the infos, and keep
>> track of the suit history
>> :)
>>
>>
>>
>> Well I'm not going to list all , but possibilities
>> are endless,
>> and if you think there's something missing or  a
>> major feature missing
>> don't hesitate to contact me to give your
>> suggestions :)
>>
>> I need to take a small break from all the coding I
>> had in the past few
>> months on the site,
>> but features will be added as my time permit.
>> And the 2nd more eye candy and dynamic interface
>> will be coming too
>> (Yakeo will be working on the design and I'll do the
>> rest  )
>>
>> Well thanks for reading,
>> and unless it's remarks pertaining to the subject of
>> this list,
>> better take it on the site's LJ or in private emails
>> as to not spam the
>> list.
>> Thanks :)
>>
>>
>> On Mon, 25 Sep 2006, Growl wrote:
>>
>> > I'm writing to let everyone know about the
>> original fursuit database which Radjin and Timduru
>> are running.  It's located at
>> http://www.fur-suit.org/  It's been running for a
>> while now but I'm fairly sure that there are quite a
>> few folks who still don't know about it.  This is a
>> user friendly and fully searchable site created to
>> capture the best representation of  your fursuits
>> for future posterity.
>> >

From dualchimera at yahoo.com  Tue Sep 26 17:29:14 2006
From: dualchimera at yahoo.com (Keeper Of Dreams)
Date: Tue, 26 Sep 2006 14:29:14 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Help..
In-Reply-To: <BAY115-DAV110209CA0CAEC83F00272FA9250@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <20060926212914.40488.qmail@web54203.mail.yahoo.com>

Try the memories section on
http://community.livejournal.com/fursuit/

It's full of tons of resources. And then there's
always the good old list at fursuit.org.

I'd suggest Matrices' site, but it seems to be down
for me (anyone else?).

And there's Brokken's website too, which shows a good
way on how to build foam musclesuits.
http://www.timberwolf.org

But I strongly suggest checking out fursuit.org and
the Livejournal fursuit community.

From mhagen_2001 at yahoo.com  Wed Sep 27 21:31:44 2006
From: mhagen_2001 at yahoo.com (Patch)
Date: Wed, 27 Sep 2006 18:31:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Leather/fake leather
In-Reply-To: <mailman.40.1159278398.5694.fursuit-list@lists.fursuit.org>
Message-ID: <20060928013144.75076.qmail@web50307.mail.yahoo.com>

I'm looking for a material I can use that will look
like leather for some imitation armor for a costume. 
Can anyone recommend something that would work?  Need
a dark walnut hue.  I'm assuming leather would be a
bit costly, so I'm seeking a substitute.

--patch

*******************************************
Homer: That baby-proofing crook wanted to sell us safety 
  covers for the electrical outlets. But I'll just draw 
  bunny faces on them to scare Maggie away.
Marge: She's not afraid of bunnies.
Homer: (ominously) She will be.

From wolph at pacifier.com  Wed Sep 27 22:40:45 2006
From: wolph at pacifier.com (Wolph Windancer)
Date: Wed, 27 Sep 2006 19:40:45 -0700
Subject: FL: Leather/fake leather
In-Reply-To: <20060928013144.75076.qmail@web50307.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20060928013144.75076.qmail@web50307.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <451B362D.5050308@pacifier.com>


>I'm looking for a material I can use that will look
>like leather for some imitation armor for a costume. 
>Can anyone recommend something that would work?  Need
>a dark walnut hue.  I'm assuming leather would be a
>bit costly, so I'm seeking a substitute.
>
>--patch
>  
>
Hey patch,

If you've got a Tandy Leather branch in your area I'd suggest giving 
them a try, you'd be surprized what you can get from the scrap bins for 
not too much money, I've gathered enough of the same type of leather to 
make shoes and boots for the SCA, and friends have gotten enough to make 
full body armor.  Scrap leather is much cheaper than new naugahide or 
vinyl.  You might also want to check out flea markets and yard sales, my 
mom makes teddy bears from old leather jackets.

-Wolph

From francisco-sender-6f5fe9 at vulpes.net  Thu Sep 28 12:09:53 2006
From: francisco-sender-6f5fe9 at vulpes.net (Francisco Azinsan)
Date: Thu, 28 Sep 2006 12:09:53 -0400
Subject: FL: Further Confusion 2007 September Mission Briefing
Message-ID: <20060928160953.GA78754@urocyon.critter.net>

Fall is just around the corner and it's time for a new briefing to all agents.
We're putting out the call for lots of things this time and look forward
to seeing all your best new techniques and sharing of information with
fellow agents in our vast tracks of programming. So without further ado,
here's the latest news. Please update your cached encrypted archives as
this email might self destruct in 30 seconds (or 3, our technical branch
has been having a few quality control issues with everyone on vacation.)

1.  Hotel Status and Overflow Hotel Announcement
2.  GOH Announcement for Jerry Pournelle
3.  Silicon Room Party
4.  Masquerade Announcement
5.  Conbook Announcement
6.  FNL Reminder
7.  Pre-Reg Price Increase
8.  Badge Art Wanted!
9.  Dealer's Room
10. Furry Market Place
11. Art Show
12. FCTV Submissions sought out
13. Panelists and Panels
14. Next public meeting

               -------------------------------------------

1.  Hotel Status and Overflow Hotel Announcement

Due to overwhelming early demand, our host hotel - the San Jose
Doubletree - is almost completely sold out of rooms. There are only a
handful left on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights. Since it is so early,
we hacked into the appropriate mainframe and managed to get an overflow
hotel:

We now have a contracted room block at the Hyatt San Jose hotel, which is
just 0.2 miles from the Doubletree. Rooms are available from Wednesday the
17th thru Monday the 22nd, with a precious 1 reservation available on the
23rd (act fast if you want it!).  The Hyatt, which will officially become
a Holiday Inn at the end of September, offers the following:

 . Free Parking
 . Free airport shuttle
 . Free in Room Internet
 . Rooms for up to four occupants

For more information on hotel amenities, visit 
<http://www.hyattsanjose.hyatt.com/hyatt/hotels/index.jsp>.

Making a reservation at the Hyatt/Holiday Inn:

Price:  $114/night.  Yes, more than the DoubleTree, but still really cheap
considering standard Bay Area rates.

Reservations:  Call (800) 233-1234 or (888) 975-1234.  Specify "Further
Confusion" as the Group when requesting a room or you will not get the
convention rate.

This is a limited block so please act quickly.  We're sorry, but at this
point we cannot process special room requests (there is no such thing as a
"fursuit floor" at the Hyatt) or offer a shuttle service between hotels.
Thankfully, its within pretty easy walking distance. 

You can find all this information and more on the hotel page:

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/hotel.php>


2.  GOH Announcement for Jerry Pournelle

Further Confusion is pleased to announce that our second GOH for FC2007
will be none other than award winning novelist and scientist, Jerry
Pournelle. We are sure that all the evil geniuses will look forward to
picking his brain for the latest developments in science, technology, and
anthropomorphic alien elephant invasion scenarios.

For all the information on Mr. Pournelle, you can find his full biography
at:

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/guests.php>


3.  Silicon Room Party

Shaken or Furred? The FC2007 Room party at Silicon is a go. If you are
in the Bay Area or planning to attend Silicon, please drop by and visit us
on October 7, 2006 from 8pm til we run out of Martini mixers or the
Chairwoman decides enough is enough.

Shaken or Furred?
FC2007 Silicon Room Party
October 7, 2006 8 pm
Room 243 San Jose Doubletree Hotel
Silicon Membership is not required but they sure can use the support and
have a reasonable day membership for $20

More info on Silicon can be found at:

<http://www.siliconventions.com/>


4.  Masquerade Announcement

Our fearless masquerade folks are up and running. This year we're
announcing a new level for the Masquerade! There will be the standard
levels like usual; Novice, Journeyman, and Master. And if you've won in
the past, you may do so again at the same level as last time! And don't be
afraid anymore of going up against professionals, because now they've got
their own category. Also, judging will be mainly on construction, so you
MUST be at the rehearsal to present your suit. Please see the website for
more information at:

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/masqinfo.php>


5.  Conbook Announcement

Our conbook submissions guidelines are now up and available. Remember, our
book is once again all color this year, so we can accept color as well as
black and white submission. The deadline for submitting art or written
materials is November 1, 2006. We also have room for a couple of short stories
and other written materials. For all the info please see the following:

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/conbook_guidelines.php>


6.  FNL Reminder 

Get ready your spy gear, decoder rings and undercover disguises, Agents!
Furry Night Live is back again on Sunday night as the number one place to
see furry variety acts performed live. Break out the shoe phone and deploy
those dashing agents, femmes fatales, and thuggish hench-bears. Your
mission, should you choose to accept it: Assemble your secret forces to
put together an act or skit fitting the spy theme "Fur Your Eyes Only."
Are you a Rogue Agent with no act or skit?  Not an Impossible Mission! Our
crack team of operatives will have scripts, acts, and skits for you to
participate in. For more information contact Furry Night Live Lead, Yippee
Coyote, at fnl at furtherconfusion.org. To subscribe to the official Furry
Night Live discussion E-mail list go to
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/fnl_signup.php>


7.  Pre-Reg Price Increase

Effective September 1st, our pre-registration rate has increased to $45.
Pre-registration will be available at that price until December 30th.  You
can reach online registration at: 

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/onlinereg.php>


8.  Badge Art Wanted!

Further Confusion is currently seeking artwork submissions for the 2007
membership badge inserts. Both color and black & white artwork will be
accepted, and all artwork will be considered on overall 'look and feel',
plus these additional points:

 . Size: Art must scale to be printed at 4" x 2".
 . Theme: Art must accurately reflect the theme of the con.
 . Age appropriateness: The art must be suitable for viewing by children.

Artists submitting images should be aware that there is no payment for
badge art chosen, and the artist gives Further Confusion the right to
reproduce the image as badge art for FC2007. The artist will be credited
on the insert and in the con program book. The artist retains all other
copyrights and reproduction rights beyond the above.

Submission deadline is November 1st, 2006. All qualifying submissions will
be seriously considered and we will choose 6 designs. All artists will be
notified by December 1st as to whether or not their submissions have been
chosen.

For more information, please see
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/badgeart.php>


9.  Dealer's Room

There were ten half-table spaces offered to people on the Dealers Room
waiting list at the beginning of August.  Not all of the dealers who were
offered the spaces accepted, so we still have a small number of spaces
open.  These will be offered again on November 1st by random drawing to
those on the waiting list at that time.  If you want to take part in the
random drawing for a half table in the dealers room, you should fill out
the waiting list form which is linked from the Dealer's Room website at
<http://furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/dealers.php> and send it back to us so
that it arrives before the November 1st deadline.


10. Furry Market Place

The first round of Furry Market Place space offers is closed, and we
filled all the spaces that we had available.  The next round will open on
November 1st, when we will be offering another 10 spaces.  These spaces
will be offered on a first-come first-served basis.  You should note that
any second round requests postmarked before November 1st will be _put
at the back of the queue_.  More details will follow in the October
mission briefing.


11. Art Show

Art Show Panel Requests are now open! We are selling out quickly and are
at about 50% of our total capacity at present. Please go to
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/artshow.php> for announcements and
further information, or send in a request for an information packet to
artshow at furtherconfusion.org.


12. FCTV Submissions sought out

Its that time of year again. Have some nifty furry video or show you'd
like to see on FCTV? Well now's the time to start the submittal process!
Right now anything with a PG or lower rating is on the table, so submit
away! Any length, any format. To submit, just send an e-mail to
fctv at furtherconfusion.org with information on your submission and we'll
take it from there! Also feel free to e-mail if there's something you
yourself didn't make, but would like to see on FCTV! We'll reach out to
content creators ourselves if we have to! Deadlines for major content
submission is November 31st (we need time to prepare it all), so if you've
got that great video idea, get filming!


13. Panelists and Panels

Our devious programming track leads are rapidly filling up the schedule to
give you too many choices once again. If you have an idea for a panel you
would like to see or run, please drop a line to
events at furtherconfusion.org. The deadline for panel ideas is November 1 (So
that we can make sure we get the panelists credit in the con book) so act
soon.


14. Next public meeting

Our next staff meeting will be October 14th starting at noon in the San
Jose Doubletree. Parking is free - just tell the parking attendant that
you're with Further Confusion when you arrive, and then get a sticker for
your parking slip in the meeting.


Oh, shush.
--
Further Confusion
info at furtherconfusion.org
http://www.furtherconfusion.org/

I always add a doubled-over layer of ultrasuede for eyelids at top and
bottom and just glue down the fur to that, shaping it around as I go.

From karen.upfront at shaw.ca  Fri Sep 29 09:43:06 2006
From: karen.upfront at shaw.ca (Karen Dollmont)
Date: Fri, 29 Sep 2006 07:43:06 -0600
Subject: FL: Eyes.
References: <c43.4066d6c.324d99c0@aol.com>
Message-ID: <001401c6e3cd$31c9fe00$6701a8c0@karen>

HI I am not sure what your eyes are made of if they are plastic then pull the fur into the hole and glue down on the foam inside. I reinforse the fur with product called goop. but hot glue should work too. If the eyes are screen run a bead of hot glue around the edge of the screen and fold the edge of the fur on to it.. We sew the fur to the sreen eyes and then add them to the foam. Hope some of that helps. 

Karen Dollmont
Up Front Mascots
toll free 866-485-9795
karen.upfront at shaw.ca
www.mascotsupfront.com

IAAPA Attractions  EXPO
November 13 - 18

From stego at cpl.net  Fri Sep 29 17:15:28 2006
From: stego at cpl.net (Stego S. Aurus)
Date: Fri, 29 Sep 2006 14:15:28 -0700
Subject: FL: Wolverine-claws DIY:
In-Reply-To: <982832d90609281523n25bf3770l9e7879de2c0ad83d@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c43.4066d6c.324d99c0@aol.com>
	<982832d90609281523n25bf3770l9e7879de2c0ad83d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <451D8CF0.7020106@cpl.net>

Hey y'all!

I found this via Fark today, and saw that it could easily fire off all 
sorts of claw-type thoughts:

  http://www.muc.muohio.edu/~natedogg/main.htm

I thought I'd share that with fellow suiters here as I know that quite a 
few have the ability to make these.

Heres a thought of my own for building retractable animal claws: Use a 
shoulder harness much like the ones that amputees use to open and close 
their hooks: stretch the back, claws come out. Relax, claws retract.

Have fun!

Stego the Rarely-Seen Dino....

I'm performing live at an amateur singing contest in my home town of
Southampton, and I'm singing "Hungry like the Wolf" by Duran Duran. I plan
to impress the judges by ripping open my shirt during the bridge and
revealing a huge wolf decal on an undershirt. However, I'd also like to howl
convincingly. Can anyone who suits or role-plays as a wolf perhaps give me
some help on how to perfect a wolf howl?

Thanks, Hedgie

hey there Super BH for me before I begin to howl like a wolf I listen to my Halloween sound effects and when I  hear some wolves howling I listen to them a few times before I begin to howl just like them so get yourself a halloween sound track on Cassette or CD (what ever works better for you) but make sure it has wolves howling on it before you buy it cuz I bought some off brands before and I barely heard any wolves howling on it, or you can download it from a program like I use Limewire and I search for howling wolves or something like that and I get it, so you can you a program almost like what I use to download music or anything like it would do so this native american dark wolf wishes you the best of luck.

From dragonsfire867 at yahoo.com  Sun Oct  1 17:10:23 2006
From: dragonsfire867 at yahoo.com (Dragonsfire)
Date: Sun, 1 Oct 2006 14:10:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Howling
In-Reply-To: <001b01c6e459$64eaa780$0b00000a@NoobSaibot>
Message-ID: <20061001211023.20116.qmail@web35509.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

One thing to remember is that no matter how you say "Ah-oooo", it's never going to come out. The proper pronunciation is "arrrr-ooooooo", but the "oo"ounds still has to keep that 'R" sound. (Kepp your jaw back for that, and experiment with how you place it). Also, stay in a diaphram-voice until you reach the "oo" part, switch into headvoice and do not worry about getting a clear sound; you want it to sound almost husky and wolf-like. Try these tips out; I hope they help.
   
  Dragonsfire

Super BH <superbh at pureandfur.freeserve.co.uk> wrote:

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Anime Cat 
  To: fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org 
  Sent: Monday, October 02, 2006 8:43 AM
  Subject: Re: FL: (no subject)


  For crying out loud... I can understand putting out a message saying "Looking for a female suiting partner" or "just curious, but how many females are there in the fandom" or something else suit-related, but out-and-out announcing that you're looking for a MATE?! Jeez. One- this is a fursuit list, as Moonstone so rightly pointed out. Two, what woman worth her salt is going to even respond to such an impersonal request? 

  You want a female, furry mate? Try chatting up someone at a con, be sweet, offer to buy her a drink, but for gosh-sakes, don't go hunting one on a mailing list! 

  This message was brought to you by AnimeCat, who is- OMG- female and furry and proud of it. 

  -AC

It's been a while since I last posted here, but I wanted to let everyone

From dragonsfire867 at yahoo.com  Mon Oct  2 15:01:33 2006
From: dragonsfire867 at yahoo.com (Dragonsfire)
Date: Mon, 2 Oct 2006 12:01:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Need help finding a costume site...
Message-ID: <20061002190134.93758.qmail@web35503.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

I went to a fursuit/costuming site sometime this summer, and I can't remember the URL or the name for it. It had a lion headpiece (a reference to Aslan) which was incredibly realistic, several latex things, an Anubis fursuit that had a gold helmet for the head as well as an actual fursuit head, plus the makings of a dragon mask that wasn't finished. There were also non-furry costumes as well. If anyone has any idea as to what the site is, I'd really appreciate if you could send me the URL. Thanks!
   
  Dragonsfire

> J. A. Michel Brassard - a.k.a. Michel Mephit

Wow.  Trevor, you must have never made it to a furry convention.  There 
are plenty of women in fandom, though it wasn't always that way.  Sadly, 
all the ones I seem to find are attached, underage or just nucking futz. 
  Makes me wonder if all the good available women go hide whenever I 
walk nearby.

Telain & Omen, there is one good benefit to being shorter than most. 
You don't hit your head on all sorts of overhanging branches, shelves, 
etc.  I'm 6'0" tall, and I can't tell you how many times I've smacked my 
head on something and had my shorter friends laugh at me.

There's a benefit and downside to everything.  The key is looking at the 
brighter side now & then.  :)

Chythar

>I went to a fursuit/costuming site sometime this summer, and I can't remember the URL or the name for it. It had a lion headpiece (a reference to Aslan) which was incredibly realistic, several latex things, an Anubis fursuit that had a gold helmet for the head as well as an actual fursuit head, plus the makings of a dragon mask that wasn't finished. There were also non-furry costumes as well. If anyone has any idea as to what the site is, I'd really appreciate if you could send me the URL. Thanks!

Most likely option is Primal Visions, at http://www.primalvisions.com/

-Emejn

In a (slight) effort to bring things back on topic.

At least to me, when I see a small petite person (male or female) in  
fursuit, they bring
about a realism and life to their character that is,.....very special.

Now, I'm by no means overweight, or excessively tall (5', 10") but I  
wish I was alot smaller
and full of energy to give my character (if you may) the life and  
spirit that I feel inside.

Oh well, I guess I fursuit for different reasons than most on this  
list do :P

-Aerofox
--
http://www.lycanthrope.net/~aerofox

>In a (slight) effort to bring things back on topic.
>
>At least to me, when I see a small petite person (male or female) in
>fursuit, they bring
>about a realism and life to their character that is,.....very special.
>
>Now, I'm by no means overweight, or excessively tall (5', 10") but I
>wish I was alot smaller
>and full of energy to give my character (if you may) the life and
>spirit that I feel inside.
>
>Oh well, I guess I fursuit for different reasons than most on this
>list do :P
>
>-Aerofox
>--
>http://www.lycanthrope.net/~aerofox
>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Chythar" <chythar at firstlight.net>

Subject: Re: FL: (no subject)


Wow.  Trevor, you must have never made it to a furry convention.  There
are plenty of women in fandom, though it wasn't always that way.  Sadly,
all the ones I seem to find are attached, underage or just nucking futz.
  Makes me wonder if all the good available women go hide whenever I
walk nearby.

Telain & Omen, there is one good benefit to being shorter than most.
You don't hit your head on all sorts of overhanging branches, shelves,
etc.  I'm 6'0" tall, and I can't tell you how many times I've smacked my
head on something and had my shorter friends laugh at me.

There's a benefit and downside to everything.  The key is looking at the
brighter side now & then.  :)

Chythar

From megaplex at pawpet.org  Tue Oct  3 01:38:37 2006
From: megaplex at pawpet.org (Megaplex 2007)
Date: Tue, 03 Oct 2006 01:38:37 -0400
Subject: FL: BIG FUN, NO WHAMMIES! #2 - Megaplex 2007 News - October 2006
Message-ID: <4521F75D.7090208@pawpet.org>

Popping up like a Daily Double in your mailbox, it's time for the latest
news on Megaplex 2007!

Florida's furry arts and entertainment convention is back for another
spin, and this time, we're bringing the fun to the First Coast!
Megaplex 2007 will be held on March 2-4, 2007, at the Wyndham
Jacksonville Riverwalk, in Jacksonville, Florida.

LET'S MEET OUR GUEST OF HONOUR!

Megaplex 2007 is happy to announce that Mike Kazaleh will be joining us
as Guest of Honour this year!  Mike is a professional animator and
comics artist; old-school furry fans will remember his comics work on
"The Adventures of Captain Jack" (Fantagraphics), and "Mean Green Bondo
Machine" and "The Suit" (MU Press).  He has also drawn "Ren and Stimpy"
for Marvel, "Cow and Chicken" for DC Comics, and "The Mighty Mutanimals"
for Archie Comics, and is currently working on "Futurama" for Bongo
Comics and "Camp Lazlo" for DC.

Animation-wise, his credits include "The New Adventures of Mighty
Mouse", "Tiny Toon Adventures", and "The Simpsons"; more recently, he
has worked on "Krypto the Superdog", "Johnny Test", and "Hi Hi Puffy Ami
Yumi".  He was also a storyboard artist for the recent release, "The Ant
Bully".

Please join us in welcoming Mike to Megaplex 2007!

HAVE YOU VISITED THE WEBSITE LATELY?

If not, you're missing out on a really cool design job, courtesy of one
Jess "Lynxcat" Kiela, our talented art director.  As the fellows in that
one commercial put it, "Brilliant!"

What can you do on http://www.ppmp.info/ ?  Well, you can register for
the convention, order your con t-shirt, reserve your dealer's room
table(s), and purchase con book advertisements and personals!  Not to
mention, we'll be updating the site regularly with news and notes to get
you ready for the con.

Also, keep an eye on our "megaplex" community on LiveJournal, for
additional information from not only the staff of Megaplex, but our
members as well!  That site is http://megaplex.livejournal.com/ .

WHAT ARE T-SHIRTS, ALEX?

We will have Megaplex 2007 t-shirts...more info on the design is coming
soon.  In the meantime, be sure to order yours when you register - we
won't have that many available beyond what is ordered, and if last year
was any indication, the extras will go fast!

T-Shirts are $12 for Small through 2X-Large when pre-ordered.

DEALERS ROOM TABLES!

Our members asked for it, so Megaplex is bringing back a traditional
Dealer Room in 2007! Bring your art, comics, clothing, DVDs - whatever
you'd like to show! Table reservations can be made when you register for
the convention. Full tables are only $40 apiece (limit two) - grab one
for yourself, or find a partner to share.

Either way, reserve early! Space is limited - first come, first served!

Please remember the rating! All materials being displayed publicly must
be no more than PG-rated. Applying labels or other coverings in order to
conceal its objectionable portions will not be acceptable.

BOO!

Furloween is coming up October 28th...check out
http://www.floridafurs.com/furloween/ for more information.  While
you're at Furloween, be sure to pick up your Megaplex 2007
flyer...there'll be a code on the flyer that will get you $5 your base
membership at Megaplex, if you register with the code by November 30th!

(To Keep The Insurance Folks Happy : Furloween is operated by Patrick
"Mach" Dowden; Pawpet Live Experiences, Inc. is in no way involved with
the operation of the event.)

WHAT'S BEHIND DOOR #1?

It's time to play!  This year, we're working up a Game Show theme that
is sure to entertain.  If you have an idea for a panel or event that
fits into our theme for 2007, drop us a line at
megaplex-feedback at pawpet.org .  We want your feedback on exactly what
you want to see at the convention, and we want to get with folks who
would like to run said panels and events.  Megaplex is ultimately the
members' convention, so help make it the best it can be!

We're always on the lookout for volunteers, as well.  Drop us a note if
you'd like to help out in March.

HOTEL RESERVATIONS OPEN!

This year, Megaplex 2007 will be held at the Wyndham Jacksonville
Riverwalk, in downtown
Jacksonville, Florida.  The hotel is just off of I-95, on the Southbank
of the St. John's
River.  Full directions can be found on our web site (http://www.ppmp.info).

The Wyndham is a short distance from the Museum of Science and History
(MOSH), Friendship Park, and River City Brewing Company, which can
easilly be reached via the Riverwalk.  The hotel is also a stop for the
S.S. Marine Taxi service (http://www.jaxwatertaxi.com), which is a
convenient way to get to the shops and restaurants at the Jacksonville
Landing (http://www.jacksonvillelanding.com).  The San Marco shopping
district is close by, and Five Points and Riverside are just over the
Fuller Warren Bridge (I-95 to Park Street).  Jacksonville International
Airport (JAX) is 20 minutes away.

Reservations at the hotel can be made ON-LINE this year!  This method
requires a credit card to use. Here's how:

1) Surf to http://www.wyndham.com/hotels/JAXHT/main.wnt .

2) Click on the "Get Rates or Make A Reservation For This Hotel" link,
just under the hotel's address.

3) On the next page...
    a. Leave "Select A Rate Plan" (Section 1) as "Best Available &
       Wyndham.com WEBRATES".
    b. Enter your arrival and departure dates (Section 2).  Remember,
       Megaplex is March 2-4, 2007.
    c. Specify # of Rooms, and folks staying in them (Section 3).
    d. Skip past Section 4, unless you're a Wyndham ByRequest member and
       want the credit.
    e. In Section 5, type the following in the "Group Code" blank :
0301886pa
    f. Click "Check Availability"

4) The next page shows the rooms available.  You should see "Pawpet Live
Experiences" as the Rate Plan, and $99/night as the rate for regular
rooms.  Click on the rate for the room of your choice to continue.

5) On the next page, double-check the selections in Sections 1-4, then
fill in Sections 5-8 and click "Confirm Reservation".

If you prefer to reserve by phone, call (904) 396-5100.  Be sure to
reference group reservation
code 0301886pa to get Megaplex's room rate.

Reserve early!  Reservations close on January 30, 2007, so get your
rooms as soon as possible!

If you have any questions on the hotel, feel free to contact Randy Fox
at mp-facility at pawpet.org.

NEXT MEETING!

We'll be holding our next face-to-face meeting in Jacksonville on
Saturday, October 14th, at 6:00pm EDT.  We will be at the Wyndham this
go-round; check our web page for directions.  Meet us in the lobby!

Before that, we're inviting folks to check out one of the cooler spots
in Jacksonville...the Jacksonville Zoo!  We'll meet up at 12:00pm at the
main gate of the zoo.  Admission is $11.00 (10% discount for AAA members
and military personnel).  We'll prowl the zoo, and answer questions
about Megaplex and the Jacksonville area as we go.  Directions to the
Jacksonville Zoo can be found at
http://www.jaxzoo.org/visit/directions.asp .

If you're not in the area, come chat with us!  We use the same IRC
server as the Funday Pawpet Show does - irc.pawpet.org 6667.  We'll be
in the #megaplex channel on most Sunday nights, during the Funday Pawpet
Show (7pm-11pm EDT), and we'll have weekday evening meetings open to the
public as well (watch this space).  If you want to learn more about
Megaplex, find out how you can help out, or just meet and greet, please
join us!

STAY TUNED!

Keep an eye on http://www.ppmp.info/ and
http://megaplex.livejournal.com/ for the latest news and information,
and please do not hesitate to drop us a line at
megaplex-feedback at pawpet.org (or to me directly at mp-ceo at pawpet.org) if
you have suggestions or questions regarding the convention.

Also, please join our dedicated mailing list for Megaplex!  Information
on joining can be found at
http://lists.pawpet.org/mailman/listinfo/megaplex-list .

Hope to see you at Megaplex 2007!

From santafox at comcast.net  Tue Oct  3 11:07:28 2006
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Tue, 03 Oct 2006 15:07:28 +0000
Subject: FL: (subject of height)
Message-ID: <100320061507.27031.45227CB00004D8940000699722007374789801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

>You hit the nail right on the head! Short fursuiters are so realistic and 
>sooooo cute!

As a 5'1" fursuiter, I'd have to concur on that feeling ;-)

> Look at Sanat fox, msot fo his characters need heigh boosts to be the right 
> proportions like roopert

I think the best thing about being short is that I can play virtually any size character that I want to build around my frame.  Santa Fox the fursuit character is just an inch or so taller than me, so he mimics my build exactly.  Roarke the Stork, with his long neck, stands nearly seven feet tall.  Rantula the Tarantula is large and wide, expanding around me in all directions.  I can pretty much build a costume to extend my body in any direction that I want to, opening up all kinds of possibilities that aren't available to taller or more heavyset fursuiters.

Rather than take up any more space in people's inboxes, I'll provide a link to an essay I wrote a while back about being small.  Hopefully it will be helpful to those smaller fursuiters out there who might be feeling a little frustrated about their size.

  http://santa-fox.livejournal.com/30949.html

Cheers,
Santa Fox
  
--
Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/

From Tripncheata at aol.com  Tue Oct  3 16:07:05 2006
From: Tripncheata at aol.com (Tripncheata at aol.com)
Date: Tue, 3 Oct 2006 16:07:05 EDT
Subject: FL: (subject of height)
Message-ID: <594.400c0c74.32541ce9@aol.com>

IM little both ways but a little bulky the problem with fursuits in they make 
muscle look like fat which in turn makes the body and head uneven, 
unfortunately there aren't many materials that have fur and stretch, (well there are but 
they will cost ya and I don't think every one can afford that.but realism is 
kind of relative, It depends when i see a realistic fursuit but a huge head it 
looks a little off.Especialy on a smaller person.but when you see one thats 
evenly sized to the separate parts and the suiter's height it really looks 
great.
-------------- next part --------------

From marcwolf at anubis-systems.com  Tue Oct  3 19:30:06 2006

Personally I wish I was taller and ligher build.

I am about 5'7 and of a stocky build.  My mcharacter is about 6' plus and
has a swimmer's build.

It has meant that when I built him I had to basically make a upper muscle
suit to give the should to hip ratio

Ah well - we can only work with what we are given.

Take care all

Marcwolf

I like the size I am: 5'7" @135#. Clothes and shoes are easy to find.
Airplane seats are no problem at all. And there are lots of costumes
that I can fit into:) Plus, it's easier to make me look bigger with
more padding then it would be to make a larger person appear smaller:)

Single Speedy!

From snglspdcat at gmail.com  Wed Oct  4 00:27:20 2006
From: snglspdcat at gmail.com (single speed cheeta)
Date: Wed, 4 Oct 2006 00:27:20 -0400
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
Message-ID: <c23fb4800610032127w77ff5101x29231e59315217e1@mail.gmail.com>

I've been thinking about the 'hind legs of canine, feline and saurian
'suits. There are alot of versions of digigrade legs out there. Most
seem bulky and out of proportion with the rest of the costume. As we
can only add material to the shape of the human leg and not subtract
anything, this seems to be an understandable trait from a design and
construction point of view. But from a biomechanical standpoint,
aren't plantigrade legs designed for bipedial motion? While digigrade
legs evolved for quadrapedial movement? Perhaps this is why adapting a
digigrade "look" to a bipedal costume usually looks akward to me. And
if the leg is at least in proportion to it's self, the occupant of the
'suit is walking *very* carefully. Mainly because there is no long-ish
platform upon which to balance the upright body in the fore and aft
directions.

Interestingly, I was practically laughed at recently for asking the
above question.

I've commissioned 'suits and had the option of including digigrade
legs on the body. But I've always opted out of this feature because I
never felt it looked all that convincing. Kind of like most sub
woofers in an audio system. More of something isn't always better. And
if it isn't convincing, I don't want it at all.

But since I like challenges and I like to buck the status quo, I've
been searching for a convincing digigrade leg design to incorporate
into a 'suit. So far, I like this from the front view:

http://www.saberfire.com/singlespeedcat/v/album26/costumes/makers/top2.jpg.html

It might be other proportions that make this look promising to me. I
haven't the experience to sort out which is what. At least not yet:)
My search continues.

What do you think about digigrade legs in a 'suit? Have you seen any
particularly nice examples? Please tell me about them.

And now back to our regular programming...

Single Speedy!

From marcwolf at anubis-systems.com  Wed Oct  4 06:01:04 2006
From: marcwolf at anubis-systems.com (David Boccabella)
Date: Wed, 4 Oct 2006 20:01:04 +1000
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
In-Reply-To: <c23fb4800610032127w77ff5101x29231e59315217e1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOIEELNDOAA.marcwolf@anubis-systems.com>

Hi Speedy

I had the same issue when making Marcwolf.  I have always seen him as
digitigrade and for a long time cound not find any nice way to do the
digitgrade stance.

After several movies - in particular Underworld and Underworld Evolutions
came out there is a decent design for digitigrade extenstion and the actors
who have used them say that the movements are very natural. Look at the
second movie as they progressed a lot with the extensions there.

Of interest - protheses designed for atheletes who have lost their lower
legs DO look digitgrade with the carbon fibre foot extension.

Now there are somne issues with a digitgrade stance - balance is one of them
but Stilt Walkers seem to get around Ok. The other is the dimensions between
leg and body.  If you look at the image on that link you will see that the
body/legs proportions are right, if the legs were say an extra 6 inches
longer then it would look too leggy.

When I finaly made Marcwolf I used the faux-digitgrade by faking it with
padding to give an optical illusion of a longer foot. On my site
http://marcwolf.org under the construction you will see 2 versions of the
legs. The first just being foam padding and the second a more detail version
that gives a very good look. Its more 'bulky' than what you might be looking
for but you can adjust the designs etc.  I got the inspiration from Marrok
:>

Creating the illlusion of a smaller foot is fairly easy by padding out the
front of the leg so that the viewer see's less of the instep. And then
making a longer line between the 'hocks' or back of the ankle to the top of
the knee will give you the psuedo calves. So in the end you have a visual
zig-zag effect for the viewer's eye to follow.

Moving is another part - I have created a cantalever between the hock and
the knee so that when I angle my own foot back - this section moves and
simulates the foot lifting and the hock moving up. I am often asked by
people if I get tired of standing on my toes in the costume - when I am
actually walking and moving plantigrade.

It also means that I am very agile and will get into football games and
other fun activities <laughs>

Anyway - have a look and if you have any Q's drop me a line.

Take Care

Marcwolf

From smrgol at optonline.net  Wed Oct  4 12:31:56 2006

Those are a good false digitigrade.

Notice that the heels are wedged about 2" to give a smaller footprint and both the upper and lower legs are well padded.  If you look closely, you can follow the straight leg.

I LIKE the suit!

From snglspdcat at gmail.com  Wed Oct  4 13:44:56 2006
From: snglspdcat at gmail.com (single speed cheeta)
Date: Wed, 4 Oct 2006 13:44:56 -0400
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
In-Reply-To: <OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOIEELNDOAA.marcwolf@anubis-systems.com>
References: <c23fb4800610032127w77ff5101x29231e59315217e1@mail.gmail.com>
	<OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOIEELNDOAA.marcwolf@anubis-systems.com>
Message-ID: <c23fb4800610041044x3df9b653p3f61232f78f061a4@mail.gmail.com>

David,

Thanks very much for the detailed descriptions of your work. That's
something along the lines of what I envision. Perhaps somewhat lighter
in appearence though. Ever since I did a mascot job during a central
Arizona summer, I've insisted on minimal padding. This cuts down on
weight, heat and maintainence. It can compromise the appearence of the
costume. This is a trade off that I willingly make. I try to
compensate for this through performance.

The character this is going to be used for is a werewolf. So I'm going
to go with a design that is somewhat more human in shape then canine.
He's also quite shaggy. Many details seem to be obscured by the fur
for the most part.

I know I won't get it 'right' this first time. But I can try. Right?

I'll take a look at the movies that you suggest. I do recall there
being alot of movement with the characters. And they did seem to get
around well. I do think that stilt walkers are pretty careful about
how they move. And that is reflected in their appearence.

I can't even imagine playing football out of 'suit! I'm too small and
lightweight for that:)

Cheers,

Single Speedy

From tim1 at timduru.org  Mon Oct  9 13:40:59 2006
From: tim1 at timduru.org (tim1 at timduru.org)
Date: Mon, 9 Oct 2006 17:40:59 +0000 (GMT)
Subject: FL: Fursuit database
In-Reply-To: <67e2edf40610090815r5f197182nb25f2a914e8d1f1a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <4025d9ef0610090700l47a4339ascf59eb40d1923419@mail.gmail.com>
	<005501c6ebac$320d1be0$6501a8c0@toasty>
	<67e2edf40610090815r5f197182nb25f2a914e8d1f1a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061009173440.G1925@j3.timduru.org>


to Aerofox or anyone else, ;)
 yep, you just have to create an account on it, then login with it to add
your fursuit(s) and photos :)

As for who did / does what:
Growl got the original first site idea
Radjin maintained the old static version and gave me the static html
of the current look to work from.
And I made all the code and the rest happen ;)

For registering you don't even have to ask us ,
but if you have suggestions or technical questions  you can send
to me or onto the LJ:
http://community.livejournal.com/fur_suits/

:o)

Yeah I have one on there its free and really cool. All you have to do is sign 
up then go to control panel and work on you profile or fursuit files 
ex:fursuiter.org - fursuit database - user profile - Omen Nightfire See its just like 
that but your profile image has to be 250 pixels, but the gallery for the 
fursuit pics can be as big as you like.

From szakal at warszawa.home.pl  Fri Oct  6 13:29:43 2006
From: szakal at warszawa.home.pl (*)
Date: Fri, 06 Oct 2006 19:29:43 +0200
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
References: <c23fb4800610032127w77ff5101x29231e59315217e1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4e24d06bb0dec9acb5d275e94747478e.qmail@home.pl>

"single speed cheeta" <snglspdcat at gmail.com> napisa?(a):
> I've been thinking about the 'hind legs of canine, feline and saurian
> 'suits. There are alot of versions of digigrade legs out there. Most
> seem bulky and out of proportion with the rest of the costume. As we
> can only add material to the shape of the human leg and not subtract
> anything, this seems to be an understandable trait from a design and
> construction point of view. But from a biomechanical standpoint,
> aren't plantigrade legs designed for bipedial motion? While digigrade
> legs evolved for quadrapedial movement? Perhaps this is why adapting a
> digigrade "look" to a bipedal costume usually looks akward to me. And
> if the leg is at least in proportion to it's self, the occupant of the
> 'suit is walking *very* carefully. Mainly because there is no long-ish
> platform upon which to balance the upright body in the fore and aft
> directions.
> 
> Interestingly, I was practically laughed at recently for asking the
> above question.
> 
> I've commissioned 'suits and had the option of including digigrade
> legs on the body. But I've always opted out of this feature because I
> never felt it looked all that convincing. Kind of like most sub
> woofers in an audio system. More of something isn't always better. And
> if it isn't convincing, I don't want it at all.
> 
> But since I like challenges and I like to buck the status quo, I've
> been searching for a convincing digigrade leg design to incorporate
> into a 'suit. So far, I like this from the front view:
> 
> http://www.saberfire.com/singlespeedcat/v/album26/costumes/makers/top2.jp
> g.html
> 
> It might be other proportions that make this look promising to me. I
> haven't the experience to sort out which is what. At least not yet:)
> My search continues.
> 
> What do you think about digigrade legs in a 'suit? Have you seen any
> particularly nice examples? Please tell me about them.
> 
> And now back to our regular programming...
> 
> Single Speedy!
> _______________________________________________
> _______________________________________________
> Fursuit Mail list.
> To edit your subscription, visit: 
> http://lists.fursuit.org/mailman/listinfo/fursuit-list


OH MY This is Beautifle. 
  And sorry, but i dont have connection now - im only for 2-5min a day so 
no time to even answer most of mails, so... i will talk with you after that 
my cable would be installed.

And no - i havent seen hind paws as good as that.

From kaffawolf at gmail.com  Tue Oct 10 09:35:27 2006

Since we're on the subject of the fursuit databases, I'm looking at
having t-shirts made for fursuiter.org. I've done this previously for
a local furry group and it was way cool! ^^

Since I'm not much of an artist, I need some help with the design. It
should be simple line art ( something reproducible on white shirts
with black ink or black shirts with white ink ) and fursuit-themed.

There's a $250 ( US Dollars ) prize ( along with 5% of future t-shirt
sale profits! ) to the winning design.

Submissions should be sent to fursuiter.org at gmail.com no later than
November 1st, 2006.

- Kaffa Wolf

From snglspdcat at gmail.com  Tue Oct 10 11:22:19 2006
From: snglspdcat at gmail.com (single speed cheeta)
Date: Tue, 10 Oct 2006 11:22:19 -0400
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
In-Reply-To: <e338d31812529.4523e1fc@optonline.net>
References: <c23fb4800610032127w77ff5101x29231e59315217e1@mail.gmail.com>
	<67e2edf40610040432wb76680di1ab794ac90763ffb@mail.gmail.com>
	<e338d31812529.4523e1fc@optonline.net>
Message-ID: <c23fb4800610100822g51c45b44pca28231d7d5f2286@mail.gmail.com>

Is there such thing as a true digigrade with bipedal biomechanics?

That's a very good observation. Like a few things that work well, it's
apparently comprised fine details like the heel wedge as well as large
ones like the shape of the quadracept padding. The foot wedge also
changes the posture of the occupant. This affects the look of the
whole 'suit.

It's nice work. The more you look, the more you can see:)

On 10/4/06, smrgol at optonline.net <smrgol at optonline.net> wrote:
>
> Those are a good false digitigrade.
>
> Notice that the heels are wedged about 2" to give a smaller footprint and both the upper and lower legs are well padded.  If you look closely, you can follow the straight leg.
>
> I LIKE the suit!

From santafox at comcast.net  Tue Oct 10 12:27:26 2006
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Tue, 10 Oct 2006 16:27:26 +0000
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
Message-ID: <101020061627.11208.452BC9EE0002388400002BC822007614389801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

> That's a very good observation. Like a few things that work well, it's
> apparently comprised fine details like the heel wedge as well as large
> ones like the shape of the quadracept padding. The foot wedge also
> changes the posture of the occupant. This affects the look of the
> whole 'suit.

I agree fully - if you want to give a convincing digitgrade walk, you have to set up your posture in a digitgrade postition - knees slightly bent, heels raised, weight on your toes.  I think this is where a some performers fall short, and where the overuse of leg padding comes into play in trying to compensate for the difficulty in maintaining the right posture.  The reality is that padding doesn't do any good if the performer isn't willing to take on the right posture and walk in the right way.

My Santa Fox fursuit character is digitgrade, and if you look at him (http://santa-fox.livejournal.com/56508.html), you can see that the padding on his legs is not extremely noticable - especially in those pictures.  I added just enough to get the faux-digitgrade look, and could probably even use a little more on the lower legs.  But, rather than overpad for effect, I rely on my ability (a product of being small all my life) to walk for hours and hours on my toes in that faux-digitgrade stance to make the character's gait convincing.

I do like heal wedges BTW - they work wonders at reminding you to maintain the right stance, and even with my natural endurance I enjoy the comfort of being able to rest my weight on them at times without dropping down into a flat-footed plantigrade stance.  I'm working wedges into the new suit that I'm currently building and I can already see where they are going to be a big help.

Cheers,
Santa Fox

--
Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/


From snglspdcat at gmail.com  Tue Oct 10 14:56:36 2006
From: snglspdcat at gmail.com (single speed cheeta)
Date: Tue, 10 Oct 2006 14:56:36 -0400
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
In-Reply-To: <101020061627.11208.452BC9EE0002388400002BC822007614389801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>
References: <101020061627.11208.452BC9EE0002388400002BC822007614389801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <c23fb4800610101156uf0fdc9eof1ed9078961d042d@mail.gmail.com>

Absolutely. I see many 'suiters at cons believe that their costume
should do all the work for their character. It's a costume and you
wear it and *poof!* you're a puppy. Or some such critter. It seems
they don't put any more thought into the character then that. I keep
saying that the costume is just part of the story. Posture and
attitude is an important part too:)

From marcwolf at anubis-systems.com  Tue Oct 10 19:02:56 2006
From: marcwolf at anubis-systems.com (David Boccabella)
Date: Wed, 11 Oct 2006 09:02:56 +1000
Subject: FL: digigrade legs
In-Reply-To: <c23fb4800610101156uf0fdc9eof1ed9078961d042d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <OMEIJPJAFKIANLCOEJOIEEABDPAA.marcwolf@anubis-systems.com>

Hi All

Or you could build an insert that will give you a digigrade stance like
this.

One is still plantigrade but the look is definately digigrade.  As I have
mentioned before the trick is to try and give the movement of the calf (the
line beteen the knee and the ankle and remember we are talking digigrade)
some realism.

I have managed to do that because the knee does bend allowing the calf and
the ankle position to swing up rather than just bending and stressing.

http://www.marcwolf.org/construct/Legs_web_2/img_17.html

http://www.marcwolf.org/construct/Legs_web_2/thumbs_3.html

Enjoy and feel free to use any idea's.

Marcwolf

well we're not here to debate who's best or not ;)

Kaffa has assured me that the domain registration was a mistake of "dns
update" on his side, so there's hope that it'll not end up in too much
drama , and maybe the 'created in 2002' bug will vanish too :)

Well anyway, as it was said before, there's not need to get nasty about
one or the other, it's not a competition,
and our goal is to give something useful to the users.

The DBs  both have their differences and all, and suiters should just
register to both :)
It's a bit more work for sure, but it should be benefits to the end users
:)


As for linking, I still have to create the link page on the fursuit db,
but I do suggest both DBs on the fursuit archive for example.
http://fursuit.timduru.org and sub pages now.


About a common creation page, yeah that could have been nice, but as you
said it's a bit too late, as the datas are quite different under.

From eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com  Thu Oct 12 21:19:03 2006
From: eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com (Jason Taipale)
Date: Thu, 12 Oct 2006 18:19:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Matierals Questions
Message-ID: <20061013011903.39996.qmail@web52512.mail.yahoo.com>

  I have a couple materials - related questions I would like to ask:

I am considering trying to build a head using the ?Fun Foam? you can find in craft stores.  (I think this is polyethylene foam.)  However, I find that the foam has a fairly pungent odor.  Does anyone know what this odor is, is it toxic, and does the smell subside enough that it would be worth building a head?
      I know that the upholstery foam gradually changes from a white to a brownish yellow.  I have seen the foam degrade just by sitting in a dark closet, only exposed to the air.  Does anyone know approximately how long the foam lasts, or if there are ways to slow the decay down?  I wonder if adding a layer of fabric, like maybe some inexpensive cotton fabric, would work?

  Finally, I?m wondering what works well for the bottom of feet.  I have some fairly thick vinyl, but I?m not too sure how well that will work.   I?ve hear of using rubber, but not too sure where to find it.  I?m not looking for anything special on the feet, just something durable that won?t wear out too quickly.
    I have scanned the FAQ, but I couldn?t find the answers I was looking for.

Thanks

From Jazmyn at pacificpuma.com  Thu Oct 12 23:53:23 2006
From: Jazmyn at pacificpuma.com (Jazmyn Concolor)

Subject: FL: Matierals Questions
In-Reply-To: <20061013011903.39996.qmail@web52512.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20061013011903.39996.qmail@web52512.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <452F0DB3.6030202@pacificpuma.com>

AVA foam, a closed cell foam, is used in helmets nowdays.  Not sure what 
fun foam is, but here is a site where it was used for making LOTR armor.

http://www.alleycatscratch.com/lotr/Armor/Cheat/FunFoam.htm

From tiresta at grics.net  Fri Oct 13 07:36:28 2006
From: tiresta at grics.net (Steve Plunkett)
Date: Fri, 13 Oct 2006 06:36:28 -0500
Subject: FL: FC panelists needed
Message-ID: <004401c6eebb$d2b43bc0$3201a8c0@Foxie>

I'm currently seeking panelists to run fursuit related panels at Further Confusion for 2007. I'm hoping to have both building and performing panels, and have a few in mind, and am also seeking ideas for new panels. I currently need panelists to handle fursuiting building panels, from basic to advanced. I'm also hoping nayone with pro experience would be willing to run a panel about their experiences as a pro, showing what it's actually like from an experienced point of view. Performance panels are always welcome, I'm hoping to find some experienced fursuiters who would be willing to share their knowledge and experiences. If you're interested in running any panels, or have a panel idea, please contact me privately at tiresta at grics.net. Thanks!

Steve Plunkett
FC 2007 Fursuit Lead

From Rollermark6 at aol.com  Fri Oct 13 16:24:00 2006
From: Rollermark6 at aol.com (Rollermark6 at aol.com)
Date: Fri, 13 Oct 2006 16:24:00 EDT
Subject: FL: Matierals Questions
Message-ID: <3ba.6f23fa03.32614fe0@aol.com>

I don't think U have to worry about fun foam being toxic. It is made for  
kids to do arts and crafts with.
I do not think you have to worry about upholstery foam decaying. Maybe in  
10-20 years!.
I have a sofa and it is not decaying, but the seats on my 1970 truck  are!
As for the bottoms of feet, I use interlocking floor mats designed for  
around your weightbench or tool box, etc. Avail. at Home Depot, Lowes,  etc.
Lightweight and easy to cut and it is made to be walked on!
 
Hope this helps, 
TILT 
_The  FURRY World of TILT_ 
(http://hometown.aol.com/rollermark6/myhomepage/index.html)

From karen.upfront at shaw.ca  Fri Oct 13 16:33:03 2006
From: karen.upfront at shaw.ca (Karen Dollmont)
Date: Fri, 13 Oct 2006 14:33:03 -0600
Subject: FL: Matierals Questions
References: <3ba.6f23fa03.32614fe0@aol.com>
Message-ID: <033301c6ef06$c86a26c0$6701a8c0@karen>

there is a company called Rubetex that has sheet rubber.. knobby one side that we use for the bottoms of our mascot feet. It is no slip and awsome, the underside is a foam type of matherial with a rubber desity.. the bottom is non skid and very durable, light and comfortable. it cuts with a utilty knife or band saw.. 
karen
Up front Mascots

  From: Rollermark6 at aol.com

  I don't think U have to worry about fun foam being toxic. It is made for kids to do arts and crafts with.
  I do not think you have to worry about upholstery foam decaying. Maybe in 10-20 years!.
  I have a sofa and it is not decaying, but the seats on my 1970 truck are!
  As for the bottoms of feet, I use interlocking floor mats designed for around your weightbench or tool box, etc. Avail. at Home Depot, Lowes, etc.
  Lightweight and easy to cut and it is made to be walked on!

From sdizzledawg at yahoo.com  Sat Oct 14 19:10:59 2006
From: sdizzledawg at yahoo.com (sdizzle sdizzle)
Date: Sat, 14 Oct 2006 16:10:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: fur on fur
In-Reply-To: <20060926134441.58588.qmail@web54210.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061014231059.22030.qmail@web37711.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Is there any convincing way to get a new fur on top of an older fur for part of a suit.  There are some thing you just can't bring yourself to using a hot glue gun.  Are there any sewing techniques or anything that would make this possible?

Do you Yahoo!?

From rsg0910 at iglou.com  Sat Oct 14 20:03:34 2006
From: rsg0910 at iglou.com (Robert Goodwin)
Date: Sat, 14 Oct 2006 20:03:34 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: FL: fur on fur
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "sdizzle sdizzle" at Oct 14, 2006 04:10:59 PM
Message-ID: <E1GYtTa-00053X-Su@shell1.iglou.com>

> Is there any convincing way to get a new fur on top of an older fur for 
> part of a suit.  There are some thing you just can't bring yourself to 
> using a hot glue gun.  Are there any sewing techniques or anything that 
> would make this possible?

Hot glue makes things stiff... A couple things to do;

You could shave the fur down where you want to put the fur patch or leave 
it as it is for a somewhat 'bubbled' or raised look depending on how much 
life or pile is left of the original fur.

Then either sew it normally, making sure the threads aren't easily seen (I 
forget the name of the stitching methods you want to use) or use a kind of 
flexible adhesive like GOOP.

(...pulling his nose out of his studies and books just long enough to post 
and read...)

-boogi-

-- 
Homepage: http://www.furnation.com/boogi/
  AIM: rg1004 / boogikat007   ICQ: 103051846
       Y!M: boogikat         MSNM: boogikat007

Sez who that a deaf person can't have fun on the net? No ears required!

From antimon at earthlink.net  Sun Oct 15 01:35:26 2006
From: antimon at earthlink.net (Antimon)
Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 01:35:26 -0400 (GMT-04:00)
Subject: FL: The Fursuit LJ community as pimped out by distintive fabrics
Message-ID: <12771065.1160890526879.JavaMail.root@elwamui-little.atl.sa.earthlink.net>

A  portion of Distinctive Fabric's latest Newsletter



If you have any doubts over which fabrics make the best costumes, don't hesitate to ask. You might also want to head over to the LiveJournal group "Fursuit" for more ideas and check out what some of our other customers have been up to - they're super creative and talented!



Check them out here:

http://community.livejournal.com/fursuit/



Have a fun and safe Halloween!

Gotta love good publicity

From deltethnia at gmail.com  Sun Oct 15 13:46:15 2006
From: deltethnia at gmail.com (Karen L.)
Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 10:46:15 -0700
Subject: FL: fur on fur
In-Reply-To: <E1GYtTa-00053X-Su@shell1.iglou.com>
References: <E1GYtTa-00053X-Su@shell1.iglou.com>
Message-ID: <5a0eeb470610151046l59fc31at9a676ff0e7e654f3@mail.gmail.com>

The cat in the hat suit that was worn in the videos that were send out a
while back as well as the one I wore for Barnes and Noble has a fur over fur
pattern to make the sketcky looking fur of the book come to life. On the
inside of the suit it looks like the stitch used was a machine stitch
zig-zag. Then the fur was brushed up out of the seams. But the fur itself
was kinda a lumpy almost curly short pile, reather like a rex cat fur that
didn't look bad mussed and rumpled. I believe perhaps carefu handstitching
may work to.

On 10/14/06, Robert Goodwin <rsg0910 at iglou.com> wrote:
>
> > Is there any convincing way to get a new fur on top of an older fur for
> > part of a suit.  There are some thing you just can't bring yourself to
> > using a hot glue gun.  Are there any sewing techniques or anything that
> > would make this possible?
>
> Hot glue makes things stiff... A couple things to do;
>
> You could shave the fur down where you want to put the fur patch or leave
> it as it is for a somewhat 'bubbled' or raised look depending on how much
> life or pile is left of the original fur.
>
> Then either sew it normally, making sure the threads aren't easily seen (I
> forget the name of the stitching methods you want to use) or use a kind of
> flexible adhesive like GOOP.
>
> (...pulling his nose out of his studies and books just long enough to post
> and read...)
>
> -boogi-
>
> --
> Homepage: http://www.furnation.com/boogi/
>   AIM: rg1004 / boogikat007   ICQ: 103051846
>        Y!M: boogikat         MSNM: boogikat007
>
> Sez who that a deaf person can't have fun on the net? No ears required!
> _______________________________________________
> _______________________________________________
> Fursuit Mail list.
> To edit your subscription, visit:
> http://lists.fursuit.org/mailman/listinfo/fursuit-list
>

From yappyfox at thefoxden.com  Sun Oct 15 17:20:35 2006
From: yappyfox at thefoxden.com (Yappy Sly Fox)
Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 17:20:35 -0400
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
Message-ID: <20061015212035.GA7065@foxpup.forest.thefoxden.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Ok, looking for discussion on this.  When the first Fursuit parade was started at 
AAC97, it was done as a way to allow the dealers who are couped up all day in the 
dealer's room and oportunity to photo and see the fursuiters they miss out on seeing 
roaming the hallways and such.  Most conventions that have started doing parades 
also followed suit, finding ways to route parades through dealer's rooms and artists 
allies.  It is a challenge sometimes, and does take a lil initiative on the part of 
con security to make things work, but the parades are usually a big enough venue to 
make such things happen.

I have learned that MFF, in it's executive descision, has decided to ban the parade 
from going into these artist's areas.  I have gotten no clear reason as to why, 
other than a "The Dealer's room lead says no, and the programming staff says it's 
final."

Well this sure defeats the initial intent of the first parades 10 years ago.  I as a 
fursuit performer and those that build suits like to show them off, and there is a 
large audience of dealer's that would probably like to see these works.  Every time 
I've been in a dealer's room, there are many dealer's with their cameras shooting 
photos along the path.  

I would hate to thing the con is catering to one person who said they didn't want 
the parade in the dealer's den, when I'm sure there are many more dealer's that wish 
to see it.

To me, if the dealer's den is avoided for the parade, it makes it not worth my time 
or effort.  I'm already roaming the halls and lobby in fursuit, and thus the regular 
attendance is already getting to see the fursuits and take photos..  and are able to 
take better photos than the time a parade quick shot would allow.

Curious to know, how many other people find that it would be a waste of effort to do 
a hall walk parade, and skip the 100 or so dealer's?

I for one, will not be in MFF's parade.



 --

I'm not a dealer but have participated in many parades, thought 
they were a lot of fun and judging by all the people with cameras 
waiting along the path it seems to be a popular event.. 

I'm curious as to why the MFF staff made such a decision, seems 
kind of silly to me.. 

BBW

From mljalpena at yahoo.com  Sun Oct 15 20:28:00 2006
From: mljalpena at yahoo.com (Mike Johnson)
Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 17:28:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
In-Reply-To: <45328DF3.29820.2A7AADB9@bigbadwolf40.comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20061016002801.68331.qmail@web52003.mail.yahoo.com>

Even as a staff member at MFF, I'm wondering it
myself.  Myself and Ocicat (who is the fursuit track
head at MFF) took this to a staff meeting recently and
we asked if we could get the parade to go back through
the dealer's den this year and we were given a no by
the Dealer's Den director himself...even after Ocicat
recieved numerous complaints about not going in the
Dealer's Den.

That's all I can say about it.  We're trying to
convince him to let the route to go back through the
Dealer's Den, but it doesn't look like it's going to
happen this year. :/

Wildfox
MFF Puppet Track Director & FVS 2nd

From antimon at earthlink.net  Sun Oct 15 22:11:35 2006

I'd probably parade anyway ass i dotn do ti for the dealer, i do it to be seen with the other suiters and still a lto fo peopel line up for the parade and get the biggest colelction of suits all in one go, also whiel you dotn get good stills in a parade I like to be in the videos.

Now if the dealers want to stage a boycot or somthing i might help.  Personally if the dealers want to see a fursuit parade they need to fight / complaign with the con staff about it, or ave all the dealer s walk out of the dealer room at that point to watch the parade (it doesn't take long )  As a suiter i'm not that worried if the dealers see me or not But if they want to see the parade I'm all for suppoting a patition or boycot to support the cause.

My desicion to participate in the parade is more so determiend by when it is held

From RTRabbitNY at aol.com  Sun Oct 15 22:25:48 2006
From: RTRabbitNY at aol.com (RTRabbitNY at aol.com)
Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 22:25:48 EDT
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
Message-ID: <576.74dd4a6.326447ac@aol.com>

I seem to be the only one who remembers this for some reason, but I was there 
so I ought to know....

That first Fursuit parade way back at AAC97 really started out more as a 
"spontaneous accident" when no audience showed up for the scheduled fursuit 
"Petting Zoo" meet & greet in the hotel ballroom.  So we decided on the spur of the 
moment not to waste the convention timeslot and march out from the ballroom 
and go all around the convention space and public areas of the hotel.  It was 
not "done as a way to allow the dealers etc.", it was just done, period.  
Regardless, it went well...so every year and con since, it was done, again and again 
etc.

Rapid T. Rabbit


In a message dated 10/15/06 5:24:14 PM Eastern Daylight Time,

It was spontanious, but when it was found that people who wanted to  
see the petting zoo could not get out of the dealer's room, that's  
when we took it to them..  I made noise and guided the group out of

> moment not to waste the convention timeslot and march out from the

> and go all around the convention space and public areas of the  
> hotel.  It was
> not "done as a way to allow the dealers etc.", it was just done,  
> period.
> Regardless, it went well...so every year and con since, it was  
> done, again and again
> etc.
>
> Rapid T. Rabbit
>
>

From flipper at phin.com  Mon Oct 16 00:46:22 2006
From: flipper at phin.com (Keith Henrickson)
Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 21:46:22 -0700
Subject: FL: MFF  fursuit parade
In-Reply-To: <5684321.1160967253029.JavaMail.root@elwamui-norfolk.atl.sa.earthlink.net>
References: <5684321.1160967253029.JavaMail.root@elwamui-norfolk.atl.sa.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <66D975D1-9815-4964-8855-D106396DDE98@phin.com>

Unfortunately, I'm not going to MFF this year due to lack of funds.

However, I think as always when suiting one needs to remember two  
things:
1. Is everyone around me having fun.
At a distant second:
2. Am I having fun?

Really, the only thing that matters is are you entertaining or  
disappointing?  If you're not entertaining people, need to change or  
not do whatever.  If you're entertaining as many people as you  
can....then keep it up.

From foxesden at hotmail.com  Mon Oct 16 08:35:18 2006
From: foxesden at hotmail.com (Foxes' Den)
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 2006 08:35:18 -0400
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
In-Reply-To: <mailman.173.1160964922.5694.fursuit-list@lists.fursuit.org>
Message-ID: <BAY110-F209769B5A393B267C1A6B7C7090@phx.gbl>


>Message: 1
>Date: Sun, 15 Oct 2006 17:20:35 -0400
>From: Yappy Sly Fox <yappyfox at thefoxden.com>
>Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.

>
>I have learned that MFF, in it's executive descision, has decided to ban 
>the parade
>from going into these artist's areas.  I have gotten no clear reason as to 
>why,
>other than a "The Dealer's room lead says no, and the programming staff 
>says it's
>final."
>

While it's been a nice gesture to offer folks in the Dealer's Room and 
Artist's Alley a view of the many fursuits on display over the weekend, the 
Fursuit Parades also offers the best opportunity for con attendees to video 
or take still pictures of the miriad of costumed critters out at the con.

IMO while the aisles in the Dealer's Den at MFF are adaquate for trapsing 
around in costume, the aisles at MFF's new, larger, Artist's Alley were 
significantly less so.

At the risk of sounding likea whiny bitch, I'd rather suit a shorter parade 
and have the stamina to be in suit longer after the parade to pose for 
stills or group shots.  Or even have the endurance left to take part in the 
Fursuit Games, if they're being held on Sunday.  By Sunday, late morning, I 
know I'm sporting a hefty load of sleep deprivation, probably haven't eaten 
as well as I should be, and have probably been in suit for 12-18 hours 
already over Friday and Saturday.

So if the Fursuit Parade needs to evolving into something new to accomodate 
the changing needs, larger spaces, and revised lay-outs of today's Furry 
Conventions then it should not resist that change.  It still serves as an 
important and popular weekend attraction that draws the same, if not more, 
attention as Two's Rant, Kage's Story Hour or the Masquarades and Variety 
Shows.  If that means that Artist's Alley and the Dealer's Rooms are "out of 
the loop" (Pun intended), then I'll make time to wander to those spaces 
during the weekend on my own so they don't miss out.

That's my take on this issue.

Swift Fox
Fursuit - Rocky the Husky
Fursuit - Safety the Firefighting Fox
Fursuit - Ashes the Fire Dog
Aspinwall Vol. Fire Department
Aspinwall, Pennsylvania

Carpet breaks down and if it is wet and cold it will form ice and be very 
dangerious to wear on the bottom of your feet. They also are very dirty and 
hard to clean.
Karen Up front mascots

>
You can also use a big-flip-flop with the thong cut off of it as the
bottom of a foot. It's very durable, though not 100% natural looking,
giving the bottom of the foot the look of a shoe, not a paw with toes.

I've heard of fun-foam being used as an accent on the head, but I
don't know about making it with fun-foam. Are you sure this is the
craft-store foam that comes in thin sheets, and is used for kids to
play with? I've never gotten any fun-foam that had a bad smell to
it... The smell might come from something that it was stored with, but
it might be dangerous if it's a different sort of foam. Also, I think
making a head with this kind of foam might be very warm.

If you're at a loss for foam, though,  you can get a foam similar to
upholstery foam (not as durable, slightly different, but fine for
making mesh-and-foam heads with, probably okay for balaclava-styled
too) in 2-inch strips at the hardware store, to use for sealing
windows with air conditioners. It's called 'Air Conditioner
Weatherseal" and it's grey, and squishy. About $3 a packet, a packet
is enough to make a small mesh head.

If the foam in the head degrades, by the time it's not worth it
anymore the head will be old and probably falling apart from use
anyway.

From mljalpena at yahoo.com  Mon Oct 16 15:02:30 2006
From: mljalpena at yahoo.com (Mike Johnson)
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 2006 12:02:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: MFF  fursuit parade
In-Reply-To: <5684321.1160967253029.JavaMail.root@elwamui-norfolk.atl.sa.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <20061016190230.49241.qmail@web52015.mail.yahoo.com>

Saturday evening is when the fursuit games and the
dance is going on at MFF so it would be hard to work
around without reshuffling events around and I'm sure
some of our fellow dancing fursuiters don't want to
march a parade in any sort of length and then go
attend the dance.  Saturday evening is also
traditionally when our "Fursuit Games" are held as
well so that evening is usually jam packed with
fursuit activities anyway.

Plus, the Dealer's Den is going to close at a bit of a
later time this year as well at MFF so the parade
would have to be around 8-9pm if we did go that route
and most of the scheduled main events have already got
their time slots settled.  Plus, you have the post
parade photoshoot which would have to be in the
ballroom (which it would be rude to interupt the dance
just so we can get all the suiters in the ballroom for
the photo) and if we do take the route outside, I'm
sure we would like some daylight to see while out
there. ;)

Wildfox
MFF Puppet Track Director (Constructed Fuzziness) &
FVS 2nd
