-----Original Message-----
From: Ocicat Snow Leopard 
Sent: Oct 15, 2006 8:55 PM
To: fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org
Subject: FL: MFF  fursuit parade


This is the second year going forward that we have not
been allowed to enter the dealer's den as part of the
MFF fursuit parade. Now, while a fursuiter, and track
lead, Im just as broken up and mystified at this
situation as the rest of you are. As track lead
believe me, I only want the best for my attendees, and
to ensure they have a good time, and stay safe in the
process. Many things were factored into the decison
NOT to go into the dealer's den last year, namely the
issue of stairs leading to the con space, a real
obstacle for many suiters to negotiate to geing with.
While many suiters can make the stairs with not
difficulty, there are a good many that simply cannot.
Since we don't have elevators that reach the bottom
floor at the MFF hotel, there is no safe way of
getting everyfur down to that area.

This year remains much the same as last year at this
point in time. The parade route(s) were discussed, and
entry into the dealer's den, art show and artist alley
were again addressed at the last staff meet. Simply
put, dealers den does not want fursuiters trapsing
through that area. Im sure there are logical reasons
why. I would love to give everyone the answer, but I
simply don't have it right now. The issue will be re
addressed at the next staff meeting in October.

 

Rest assured there are solutions to this problem, and
I encourage everfur to calm down, relax, have some
dip, and wait. We're working on the problem, and will
do our best to satisfy everyone. Keep in mind
'everyone' includes suiters and non suiters alike. If
the dealers choose not to allow us to enter their
space, or don't want us there, that is their decision.
I know a number of dealers complained that they missed
the parade last year, believing the parade would wind
down to their con space. I know certainly since MFF's
inception the parade's route has included the dealers
den. The parade route is tradion, it's a part of the
con, it lets the hard working dealers see and be
entertained by the fursuits, I know how important of a
social event the parade is, and how well attended it
is. To deny any of our hard working dealers a chance
to see the parade isn't fair, but if that's the way
they want it- so be it.

Im doing all I can for you my fellow suiters- we will
find an answer... 

 

- Ocicat

MFF Constructed Fuzziness track lead 


 



---------------------------------

From wallyfox98 at hotmail.com  Mon Oct 16 15:47:28 2006
From: wallyfox98 at hotmail.com (Wally_Wabbit/Stephen H./Wallyfox)
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 2006 15:47:28 -0400
Subject: FL: Furfright Dinner Update
In-Reply-To: <20061016190230.49241.qmail@web52015.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <BAY116-F303B23E222BCC2CEEDC2EED0090@phx.gbl>

Update!!

On Friday 10/20 I will be hosting a dinner for all those who enjoy the art 
of Fursuiting at Furfright.

We will be meeting in the lobby near the hotel desk at 5pm and from there we 
will carpool/bus/shuttle/ or walk to a restaurant.

The exact restaraunt will be determined sometime later in the week (depends 
on the size of the group)

Just to clarify,  this is NOT and "in suit" dinner gathering.  It is a 
dinner open to anyone that is a fursuiter.

If you are planning on attending please RVSP to me no later than Wednesday 
afternoon.

I will be calling up restaurants on Wednesday night if we have a large count 
by then.  If not we will determine our eatery on Friday.

snugs

Wally_Wabbit

Wally_Wabbit on Furrymuck and Tapestries
Wally_Wabbit on IRC/Yiffnet/Anthrochat
wallyfox2001 on yahoo messenger
http://www.livejournal.com/users/wally_wabbit/



From iluvferrets53187 at aol.com  Tue Oct 17 01:33:22 2006
From: iluvferrets53187 at aol.com (iluvferrets53187 at aol.com)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 01:33:22 -0400
Subject: FL:  "Butt-plate" for large tails?
Message-ID: <8C8BFC4E52399A3-880-3AFE@WEBMAIL-RA21.sysops.aol.com>

 Hey all,
 I'm working on a raptor partial-suit, and have ran into some difficulty with the 4ft tail. As some may know, a raptors tail sticks straight out, and that makes it kinda hard to simulate. The obvious solution is some sort of butt brace that is durable enough to support it. Its made of foam, so its not *that* heavy, but balancing it so it doesn't drag the ground is another matter. I've never used a butt-plate before. Is that something you can buy at a sports store? Any recommendations for possibly making one myself cheaply? Also, would it need shoulder straps like a harness to help keep it up too? Any info is greatly appreciated!
 
 Thanks,
 ~Jackie Randa

From helvetica at dslextreme.com  Tue Oct 17 02:21:43 2006
From: helvetica at dslextreme.com (Phillip Burgess)
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 2006 23:21:43 -0700
Subject: FL: "Butt-plate" for large tails?
In-Reply-To: <8C8BFC4E52399A3-880-3AFE@WEBMAIL-RA21.sysops.aol.com>
References: <8C8BFC4E52399A3-880-3AFE@WEBMAIL-RA21.sysops.aol.com>
Message-ID: <4A198797-D932-48BA-998A-91100771F386@dslextreme.com>

Butt-plates? can be found in the "Beyond" section of Bed Bath & Beyond.

Just kidding.

For Scabrous the dragon I made a tail armature and butt-plate from  
foamed PVC sheeting (available from Tap Plastics, though other  
decently-equipped plastics supply and signage shops may carry it).   
Just a few dollars' worth from the scrap bin.  The butt-plate portion  
was curved using a heat gun to better conform to the rounded  
posterior profile.

Unfortunately I didn't take many pictures of the construction  
process, but an internals-and-completed view can be seen here:

     http://members.dslextreme.com/users/pburgess/scab-tail- 
internals.jpg

The butt-plate can be seen in the left center area of the top photo.   
Note also (in the lower photo) the semi-rigid extension into the belt  
(heat-bent Delrin rod, another Tap item) which helps anchor the base  
of the tail.  Plate and rod are joined by heavy-gauge wire.

The "finished" photo doesn't show the shoulder straps which were  
added shortly thereafter.  Highly recommended, if for no other reason  
than as a fallback in case the waist belt should fail (happened once  
with another suit).

-- Phil

From jc2blion at taconic.net  Tue Oct 17 08:16:42 2006
From: jc2blion at taconic.net (Kamau)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 08:16:42 -0400
Subject: FL: "Butt-plate" for large tails?
References: <8C8BFC4E52399A3-880-3AFE@WEBMAIL-RA21.sysops.aol.com>
Message-ID: <004001c6f1e6$1bacf650$0c00a8c0@Mufasa>

One thing you might consider is rather then simply a butt plate is to use a 
harness that would allow you to have an 'external spine' and spread any 
weight out over your shoulders and back.  Even with light tails I find that 
hanging them from a belt or across your hips can be uncomfortable and make 
them somewhat unstable.  A harness would keep the tail aligned more to your 
body as I believe a raptor's tail is suppose to be.  Inexpensive harnesses 
could be found at surplus store or at Big Lots and the such.

Kamau

From donkeyears at gmail.com  Tue Oct 17 11:20:11 2006
From: donkeyears at gmail.com (Donkey)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 08:20:11 -0700
Subject: FL: animating ones hoofed fursuit.
Message-ID: <d23d76ca0610170820h56155564of69b956e504d8a94@mail.gmail.com>

That's one place that I feel that I fall short in. I never think that I give
a good performance for my suits. My problem in trying to think of how to
act. I am a hoof and hoofed animals are not that animated. For the most part
there just walking to the next tuff of grass to eat. I have watched my horse
and donkey for hours. If I did not like just watching them, I would have
been put to sleep by there lack of doing anything.

His Most Royal Highass, Donkey

On 10/10/06, single speed cheeta <snglspdcat at gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Absolutely. I see many 'suiters at cons believe that their costume
> should do all the work for their character. It's a costume and you
> wear it and *poof!* you're a puppy. Or some such critter. It seems
> they don't put any more thought into the character then that. I keep
> saying that the costume is just part of the story. Posture and
> attitude is an important part too:)
>
> On 10/10/06, Santa Fox <santafox at comcast.net> wrote:
> > > That's a very good observation. Like a few things that work well, it's
> > > apparently comprised fine details like the heel wedge as well as large
> > > ones like the shape of the quadracept padding. The foot wedge also
> > > changes the posture of the occupant. This affects the look of the
> > > whole 'suit.
> >
> > I agree fully - if you want to give a convincing digitgrade walk, you
> have to set up your posture in a digitgrade postition - knees slightly bent,
> heels raised, weight on your toes.  I think this is where a some performers
> fall short, and where the overuse of leg padding comes into play in trying
> to compensate for the difficulty in maintaining the right posture.  The
> reality is that padding doesn't do any good if the performer isn't willing
> to take on the right posture and walk in the right way.
> >
> > My Santa Fox fursuit character is digitgrade, and if you look at him (
> http://santa-fox.livejournal.com/56508.html), you can see that the padding
> on his legs is not extremely noticable - especially in those pictures.  I
> added just enough to get the faux-digitgrade look, and could probably even
> use a little more on the lower legs.  But, rather than overpad for effect, I
> rely on my ability (a product of being small all my life) to walk for hours
> and hours on my toes in that faux-digitgrade stance to make the character's
> gait convincing.
> >
> > I do like heal wedges BTW - they work wonders at reminding you to
> maintain the right stance, and even with my natural endurance I enjoy the
> comfort of being able to rest my weight on them at times without dropping
> down into a flat-footed plantigrade stance.  I'm working wedges into the new
> suit that I'm currently building and I can already see where they are going
> to be a big help.
> >
> > Cheers,
> > Santa Fox
> >
> > --
> > Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/
> >

> > _______________________________________________

From santafox at comcast.net  Tue Oct 17 12:07:03 2006
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 16:07:03 +0000
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
Message-ID: <101720061607.8849.4534FFA7000201F70000229122068246939801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

I've been away from email since Friday, so I just got caught up on this thread.  As the fursuit track director at FWA now, I've been reading this thread with great interest, since we have a new hotel for FWA 2007 and I'm going to have to create a parade route through our new con space that's going to have to work well for everyone. (BTW, pre-reg now: you don't want to miss out on all the fun and excitement of the new-and-improved FWA 2007: www.furryweekend.com)

I personally have a number of mixed feelings on parades, and a short while ago, I wrote in my LJ about some of the things that bug me about cons, and one of the things I said was this:

> Fursuit parades and the group photo. I've lost a lot of interest in these at cons
> like MFM that have so many suiters now, because I feel like just one of the 
> crowd, and it's so hard to stick out and get noticed when you're marching in the > parade line or standing in a pose with fifty-plus other suiters. Especially when 
> you're small, like me.

I think one of the most important changes over the last ten years is that the number of fursuiters in the fandom has probably quadrupled.  I'd love to know the suiter headcount at AC97 - my educated guess would be under fifty.  I think this year there was what - over three hundred?  MFM's parade this year had about seventy suiters, I think, but in any case it was a pretty large group.  It's just a fact of life that the more suiters in a parade, the slower it will go and the more accessible the path has to be to ensure that everyone gets through safely.  On the other hand, at RCFM this year, we had maybe twenty suiters tops, so we could go pretty much anywhere, since we were in and out of rooms in just a few minutes.  

I can definitely understand the important issue of avoiding steps, and while I haven't seen the MFF hotel yet, I know that the steps into the MFM dealers den always pose a problem for some, and were a reason why the MFM parade did not go through their dealer's den this year.  I can only imagine the dificulties if all suiters had to go from one floor of a building to another up or down a narrow staircase.  I'm ususally pretty good with stairs, but even I tripped up several times in the stairwells at MFM last month.  Fortunately, the new FWA parade route is going to stay completely on the main convention floor of the new hotel and will not have any steps up or down anywhere, so I know that will in and of itself be a joy for many suiters.  

On the main subject of this thread - dealers dens - I have to admit that one of the downsides to parading through dealers dens is that I feel like I have to be very contained in my antics for fear of knocking over something valuable.  On parades in some dens, I've felt like I had to just shuffle my way through, giving no more than a wave and an occasional bounce forward.  To me, that's no fun at all, and is why I make a point at every con I attend to wander through the dealers den in fursuit on my own at least two or three times during the con.  This way, I can take my time going through, can stop and pose for pictures wherever I want, and can actually spend time doing some shtick for those dealers who take more than a passing interest in me.  I would be far more irked if fursuiters were banned completely from a con's dealers den, than to just have parade access denied.

As of right now, plans are for the FWA fursuit parade to continue going through the dealers den, and hopefully the journey will be even easier than in past years.  I don't foresee any problems, but I'm still going to work with our dealer's den head to try to ensure that the room is laid out in a way that will allow the parade to pass through with the least amount of potential difficulty.

As for MFF, I plan to participate in the parade regardless of what happens - this may be my only time there for a good while, so I want to make the most of it.  I plan to visit the dealer's den on my own in suit if they'll let me, but if they won't, I'll certainly be irked but I'm not going to let that stop me from having a good time at the con.  I'll just have to find other ways to get my fursuiting kicks.

Cheers,
Santa Fox

--
Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/

From chakawolf at hotmail.com  Tue Oct 17 14:33:34 2006

Here is one of my pet complaints about fursuit parades:

Would someone please bring a jam box or something and play some music during 
the parade? I hate those silent death-march parades! I'd bring one myself, 
but I usually fly and there isn't room.  No big deal, but it makes the 
parade so much livelier.

From santafox at comcast.net  Tue Oct 17 15:36:03 2006
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 19:36:03 +0000
Subject: FL: Opinions.. Fursuit Parades.
Message-ID: <101720061936.7121.453530A30005930D00001BD122070208539801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

> What con was it that si havign 2 parades a day and an evening? was that mff 
> or fwa? or fc? soem con soon or recently i read was ahvign 2 

Draconis came up with the idea of a "Midnight Prowl Parade" for RCFM this year.  Being the GPOH there, I led that one off as Rantula the Tarantula, and I liked it the concept so much that I borrowed the idea for my planning for FWA 2007.  In the meantime, I decided at the last moment to organize an unofficial midnight parade at MFM this year.  I might try to do the same thing at MFF if they don't do one of their own accord.

Don't know whether any other cons do a second parade.  I personally think the midnight parade is a good change of pace and, of course, it gives suiters the chance to parade in a different costume if they own multiple suits.  I also like the idea of keeping them simple, staying mostly to the hallways, lobbys and other open spaces, and letting it end at the nightly dance rather than in a group photo somewhere.  

Cheers,
Santa Fox

--
Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/

From snglspdcat at gmail.com  Tue Oct 17 15:50:25 2006

Silly as it may seem, I'm actually not sure what to do during a
parade. Wave at people and keep moving or slow down and pose for pics.
I usually opt for the former because the latter jams up the flow of
traffic and makes an already long parade even longer. Mebbe more
people should shoot videos!

As for noise during a parade, I say the more the better. Within reason
of course. I agree with Chaka that a silent parade doesn't look very
appealing. How does that sound? *chuckles*

What's the big deal about skipping the dealer's den? Suiters are not
wanted there. So what? A short parade is okay!

I have never attended nor heard of a con that featured two parades.
FC, EF or otherwise.

Single Speed! (who is not attending MFF but spending Turkey Day week in so_cal)

--- Santa Fox <santafox at comcast.net> wrote:

> I've been away from email since Friday, so I just
> got caught up on this thread.  As the fursuit track
> director at FWA now, I've been reading this thread
> with great interest, since we have a new hotel for
> FWA 2007 and I'm going to have to create a parade
> route through our new con space that's going to have
> to work well for everyone. (BTW, pre-reg now: you
> don't want to miss out on all the fun and excitement
> of the new-and-improved FWA 2007:
> www.furryweekend.com)
> 
> I personally have a number of mixed feelings on
> parades, and a short while ago, I wrote in my LJ
> about some of the things that bug me about cons, and
> one of the things I said was this:
> 
> > Fursuit parades and the group photo. I've lost a
> lot of interest in these at cons
> > like MFM that have so many suiters now, because I
> feel like just one of the 
> > crowd, and it's so hard to stick out and get
> noticed when you're marching in the > parade line or
> standing in a pose with fifty-plus other suiters.
> Especially when 
> > you're small, like me.
> 
> I think one of the most important changes over the
> last ten years is that the number of fursuiters in
> the fandom has probably quadrupled.  I'd love to
> know the suiter headcount at AC97 - my educated
> guess would be under fifty.  I think this year there
> was what - over three hundred?  MFM's parade this
> year had about seventy suiters, I think, but in any
> case it was a pretty large group.  It's just a fact
> of life that the more suiters in a parade, the
> slower it will go and the more accessible the path
> has to be to ensure that everyone gets through
> safely.  On the other hand, at RCFM this year, we
> had maybe twenty suiters tops, so we could go pretty
> much anywhere, since we were in and out of rooms in
> just a few minutes.  
> 
> I can definitely understand the important issue of
> avoiding steps, and while I haven't seen the MFF
> hotel yet, I know that the steps into the MFM
> dealers den always pose a problem for some, and were
> a reason why the MFM parade did not go through their
> dealer's den this year.  I can only imagine the
> dificulties if all suiters had to go from one floor
> of a building to another up or down a narrow
> staircase.  I'm ususally pretty good with stairs,
> but even I tripped up several times in the
> stairwells at MFM last month.  Fortunately, the new
> FWA parade route is going to stay completely on the
> main convention floor of the new hotel and will not
> have any steps up or down anywhere, so I know that
> will in and of itself be a joy for many suiters.  
> 
> On the main subject of this thread - dealers dens -
> I have to admit that one of the downsides to
> parading through dealers dens is that I feel like I
> have to be very contained in my antics for fear of
> knocking over something valuable.  On parades in
> some dens, I've felt like I had to just shuffle my
> way through, giving no more than a wave and an
> occasional bounce forward.  To me, that's no fun at
> all, and is why I make a point at every con I attend
> to wander through the dealers den in fursuit on my
> own at least two or three times during the con. 
> This way, I can take my time going through, can stop
> and pose for pictures wherever I want, and can
> actually spend time doing some shtick for those
> dealers who take more than a passing interest in me.
>  I would be far more irked if fursuiters were banned
> completely from a con's dealers den, than to just
> have parade access denied.
> 
> As of right now, plans are for the FWA fursuit
> parade to continue going through the dealers den,
> and hopefully the journey will be even easier than
> in past years.  I don't foresee any problems, but
> I'm still going to work with our dealer's den head
> to try to ensure that the room is laid out in a way
> that will allow the parade to pass through with the
> least amount of potential difficulty.
> 
> As for MFF, I plan to participate in the parade
> regardless of what happens - this may be my only
> time there for a good while, so I want to make the
> most of it.  I plan to visit the dealer's den on my
> own in suit if they'll let me, but if they won't,
> I'll certainly be irked but I'm not going to let
> that stop me from having a good time at the con. 
> I'll just have to find other ways to get my
> fursuiting kicks.
> 
> Cheers,
> Santa Fox
> 
> --
> Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/
> _______________________________________________
> _______________________________________________
> Fursuit Mail list.
> To edit your subscription, visit:
>

At our yearly "Procession of the Species" in Olympia, Washington
we feature a lot of simple percussion throughout the parade. It
ads magic to our movements and creates excitement. A small
group with hand drums and shake gourds here and there does
the trick. Or treat.

Roar.

Edward
Lion of Yelm


On Oct 17, 2006, at 12:50 PM, single speed cheeta wrote:

> Silly as it may seem, I'm actually not sure what to do during a
> parade. Wave at people and keep moving or slow down and pose for pics.
> I usually opt for the former because the latter jams up the flow of
> traffic and makes an already long parade even longer. Mebbe more
> people should shoot videos!
>
> As for noise during a parade, I say the more the better. Within reason
> of course. I agree with Chaka that a silent parade doesn't look very
> appealing. How does that sound? *chuckles*
>
> What's the big deal about skipping the dealer's den? Suiters are not
> wanted there. So what? A short parade is okay!
>
> I have never attended nor heard of a con that featured two parades.
> FC, EF or otherwise.
>
> Single Speed! (who is not attending MFF but spending Turkey Day week 
> in so_cal)

usually, with exception to a few cons  most cons fursuit about 10% of  
total attendee  so like ac = 2000 attendee, parade sees 200.

megaplex turned 50 suits out for 200 attendees, so it had a bit  
higher ratio, but as general rule, 10% seems to fit most cons.

I feel that the proportion of suiters to non-suiters have changed.

I've been going to fur cons since 1997 and didn't have a fursuit  
untill 2000.
Many other furs I know who have been going to cons as long ago are now
getting or have fursuits where they didn't years back.

I knew I wanted one back then, I just didn't have the means or help  
to get
furred up ^_^

-Aerofox

From grey_llama at yahoo.com  Tue Oct 17 17:48:01 2006
From: grey_llama at yahoo.com (Sean Rook)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 14:48:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Opinions.. Fursuit Parades
In-Reply-To: <mailman.213.1161120725.5694.fursuit-list@lists.fursuit.org>
Message-ID: <20061017214801.28035.qmail@web30403.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

I may be wrong but I believe FurFright was planning
multiple fursuiter type events, possibly a second
parade.

The number of fursuits probably has increased due to
income matching interest.  I knew before I even got
into furry that I wanted a mascot type outfit, never
considered that it could be made for me privately
until after I found out about the fandom.  Then of
course it takes time and money to actually acquire
one.  You generally don't come into the fandom with
your own suit :P
Plus, I think it has to be noted that those who own
multiple suits seem to be increasingly allowing
friends and mates to wear one of them and join in on
the fun.

Has there ever been a comparison of number of
fursuiters versus total convention headcount for each
con?  AC has the most membership and fursuiters
overall but I'm betting ratio wise the medium cons
have the largest percentage of suiters.


One thing I'm curious about (if it hasn't been
discussed already), anybody have any feelings about
parade length?  The parade at MFF last year was oh so
short after excluding the dealer's room; on the
flipside, the parade at this past AC was pretty damn
long thanks to the new location.
Personally, I prefer the longer parades - you gotta
get used to the sweating if you're in suit, and it's
hard to get enough of seeing so many together. 
Though, I could do with fewer stops and maybe if
something could be done to make it more entertaining
than just a long line of fursuits.  Gotta also spread
out the more active suiters, otherwise some seem to
get lost in the crowd.

-Freaky Lynx

http://mail.yahoo.com

Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 17:55:17 -0400
Subject: FL: Opinions.. Fursuit Parades
In-Reply-To: <20061017214801.28035.qmail@web30403.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

>
>
> One thing I'm curious about (if it hasn't been
> discussed already), anybody have any feelings about
> parade length?  The parade at MFF last year was oh so
> short after excluding the dealer's room; on the
> flipside, the parade at this past AC was pretty damn
> long thanks to the new location.
> Personally, I prefer the longer parades - you gotta
> get used to the sweating if you're in suit, and it's
> hard to get enough of seeing so many together.
> Though, I could do with fewer stops and maybe if
> something could be done to make it more entertaining
> than just a long line of fursuits.  Gotta also spread
> out the more active suiters, otherwise some seem to
> get lost in the crowd.
>

The multiple stops along AC's parade route were to allow photo ops   
(The stop above the dealer's room, and then off the balcony)

there is no rule that one can't do their own antics along the parade  
route, as long as it doesn't hurt anyone, or slow down the procession.

also the stops help those that get winded catch their  breath a lil.   
yes AC was a marathon route, but, even after the exhaustion, I felt  
great afterwards..  At least it was indoor..  try doing that same  
length parade, outside, in FL heat when it's 98 degrees, in the magic  
kingdom, every day a 3pm...  and having to maintain a high energy  
level performance as you go..    comparitevly, the AC parade was a  
cake walk.     Now I know for many new suiters, it was dificult, but  
practice will bring up endurance.





> -Freaky Lynx

Why so many suits now?  I think it's easier to buy, or make your own suit
due to finding information on the Internet.  There are a lot of websites,
and Communities that help people find or build, their perfect costume.

About the parade: Let's do it anyway.  If people in the Den don't want us,
so be us, we can walk outside of it and they can come out if they wanna
oogle us!!

-J (who will have a new suit, Godiva the Chocolate Skunk at MFF)

> listinfo/fursuit-list

Actually, we had a boom box at EF. The fursuiter who led the parade had a
boom box that played silly dance music (vengaboys and the like). People
really seemed to like it, even the non-furry folks who were there outside of
the con site seemed to like all those "strange mascot things" dancing around
to that silly music.

I'd give it a shot.

-BBF

From Rollermark6 at aol.com  Tue Oct 17 21:45:23 2006
From: Rollermark6 at aol.com (Rollermark6 at aol.com)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 21:45:23 EDT
Subject: FL: "Butt-plate" for large tails?
Message-ID: <24a.d195aba.3266e133@aol.com>

For my long tails I use a "butt plate" made from the top (or bottom)of a  
plastic 55 gallon drum (Or a trash can would work) With some padding so as not  
to dig into my spine and the whole thing just attaches with a belt around my  
waist.
TILT

From anthrobunny at gmail.com  Tue Oct 17 22:45:44 2006
From: anthrobunny at gmail.com (Blackberry)
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 2006 19:45:44 -0700
Subject: FL: "Butt-plate" for large tails?
In-Reply-To: <24a.d195aba.3266e133@aol.com>
References: <24a.d195aba.3266e133@aol.com>
Message-ID: <982832d90610171945i65fb48f1xf909e58a8801f67c@mail.gmail.com>

On 10/17/06, Rollermark6 at aol.com <Rollermark6 at aol.com> wrote:
>
> For my long tails I use a "butt plate" made from the top (or bottom)of a
> plastic 55 gallon drum (Or a trash can would work) With some padding so as
> not to dig into my spine and the whole thing just attaches with a belt
> around my waist.

So far I've only made rabbit and horse tails.  The base plate I use
for those is the top of the lid for a spindle of CDROMs or DVDROMs,
with slats cut into it to allow the nylon cording through.

Yep, the music definitely was a nice addon,
as you say , even the tourists around were enjoying it seeing all the
suiters moving to it :)
As for the cymbals and other squeeky and noisy things, it might be
interesting to get multiple boxes, as people in the back of the parade
couldn't hear anything. :)

And if you go for a sound system, better not choose a cd player like mine
;)
it was skipping badly with every little shock at EF ;)
Maybe go for some tape or mp3 memory card stereo player or something :)

From eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com  Thu Oct 19 22:22:01 2006
From: eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com (Jason Taipale)
Date: Thu, 19 Oct 2006 19:22:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Undersuits
Message-ID: <20061020022201.60182.qmail@web52508.mail.yahoo.com>

  I was looking through the FAQ, and found Sardog?s opinion on using a unitard as an undersuit.  My first question is about material.  In the FAQ, Sardog recommends cotton.  I do know that Cotton is an absorbent matieral.  Nylon and Polyester are not as absorbent.  (Nylon is what Under Armour uses for Heat Gear shorts, and polyester for Heat Gear shirts.  I haven?t been able to figure out why they use different materials for the shirt and shorts.  Nor have I seen a polyester unitard anyway).  Is the absorptive property of cotton something useful in the mascot/fursuit environment?
    Secondly, I was wondering if anyone had any experiences or opinions of a unitard that has fingers and or a hood?
   Thanks
 		
---------------------------------
Yahoo! Messenger with Voice. Make PC-to-Phone Calls to the US (and 30+ countries) for 2?/min or less.
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: http://lists.fursuit.org/mailman/private/fursuit-list/attachments/20061019/af0a14fd/attachment.htm 

From sardognsca at yahoo.com  Fri Oct 20 07:10:17 2006
From: sardognsca at yahoo.com (Sardog)
Date: Fri, 20 Oct 2006 04:10:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Undersuits
Message-ID: <20061020111017.83659.qmail@web51608.mail.yahoo.com>

Hey;

I think the main reason for cotton, and, the absorbant nature of cotton is that it would retain the sweat your body gives off, as opposed to an underarmour type thing where the whole purpose is to transmit the sweat away from your body.

So, why do we want it retain?  Well, one of the main reasons for wearing the suit is to aid in keeping the suits clean.  So... You sweat, it transfers to the cotton undersuit, you wash the undersuit.  

Also, at the time that I wrote that, I don't believe that underarmor was a significant player in the market, if they existed at all.  I can say that we are currently evaluating the use of UA and it's alternatives, as an option for undersuits.

I would avoid the use of a suit with built in hands.  Your hands seem to be a major cooling point. Plus, it could affect your dexterity for doing up zippers, etc.

As for the hoods..  I can only recommend them, although most of our people don't wear them.  (Yet complain bitterly when the long hair gets in their eyes) If nothing else, it helps stabilize their hair.  However, again, creates an effective barrier between their body and the suit.

S.




----- Original Message ----
From: Jason Taipale <eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com>
To: fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org
Sent: Thursday, October 19, 2006 11:22:01 PM
Subject: FL: Undersuits


I was looking through the FAQ, and found Sardog?s opinion on using a unitard as an undersuit.  My first question is about material.  In the FAQ, Sardog recommends cotton.  I do know that Cotton is an absorbent matieral.  Nylon and Polyester are not as absorbent.  (Nylon is what Under Armour uses for Heat Gear shorts, and polyester for Heat Gear shirts.  I haven?t been able to figure out why they use different materials for the shirt and shorts.  Nor have I seen a polyester unitard anyway).  Is the absorptive property of cotton something useful in the mascot/fursuit environment?
Secondly, I was wondering if anyone had any experiences or opinions of a unitard that has fingers and or a hood?
Thanks

From sardognsca at yahoo.com  Sat Oct 21 18:47:25 2006
From: sardognsca at yahoo.com (Sardog)
Date: Sat, 21 Oct 2006 15:47:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Undersuits (Furtech,
	if you're still monitoring this list... I'd value your opinions)
Message-ID: <20061021224725.12143.qmail@web51611.mail.yahoo.com>

Hey All;

I thought I'd update a note on this file...  

I spoke with the gear manufacturer for a similar brand to UnderArmour. Since they are already a sponsor of ours, I brought it up about using the UA for under the suits.

The conversation went something like this...

Me:. We'd like to issue UA to our mascots, to provide a barrier between our performers and the suits.

SR: These are your mascots??..

Me: Yes, we're finding our performers wearing various degrees of clothing under the suits, from the bear minimums, ie. underwear, to gym shorts etc.

SR: So, you want to use UA to isolate...

Me: Yes.

SR: Don't recommend it... UA is designed to transfer sweat away from an athletes (or performers body) to the next level of clothing  In this case, you'd be transfering the sweat from the performers, to the suits..  I'd recommend a cotton or similar material that will absorb the sweat, so that when they change, the bulk of the nastiness goes with the performer.

This would be a good time for Furtech to chime in with his opinon.

S. 


----- Original Message ----
From: J.T. Beckett <>
To: sardognsca at yahoo.com
Sent: Saturday, October 21, 2006 12:24:26 PM
Subject: Re: FL: Undersuits


I've found some incredibly awesome fabric that is a supplex, and it's 
completely waterproof... yet comfortable like cotton, and strechy like 
spandex.  My hubby wears it for his performances (not in suit... but his 
show is HIGHLY aerobic)  he can do two 45 minute sets and be sweating like 
crazy under the shirt, but there's not a drop of sweat to be seen on the 
outside of the shirt.


>From: Sardog <sardognsca at yahoo.com>
>Reply-To: Sardog <sardognsca at yahoo.com>, fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org
>To: fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org
>Subject: Re: FL: Undersuits
>Date: Fri, 20 Oct 2006 04:10:17 -0700 (PDT)
>
>Hey;
>
>I think the main reason for cotton, and, the absorbant nature of cotton is 
>that it would retain the sweat your body gives off, as opposed to an 
>underarmour type thing where the whole purpose is to transmit the sweat 
>away from your body.
>
>So, why do we want it retain?  Well, one of the main reasons for wearing 
>the suit is to aid in keeping the suits clean.  So... You sweat, it 
>transfers to the cotton undersuit, you wash the undersuit.
>
>Also, at the time that I wrote that, I don't believe that underarmor was a 
>significant player in the market, if they existed at all.  I can say that 
>we are currently evaluating the use of UA and it's alternatives, as an 
>option for undersuits.
>
>I would avoid the use of a suit with built in hands.  Your hands seem to be 
>a major cooling point. Plus, it could affect your dexterity for doing up 
>zippers, etc.
>
>As for the hoods..  I can only recommend them, although most of our people 
>don't wear them.  (Yet complain bitterly when the long hair gets in their 
>eyes) If nothing else, it helps stabilize their hair.  However, again, 
>creates an effective barrier between their body and the suit.
>
>S.
>
>
>
>
>----- Original Message ----
>From: Jason Taipale <eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com>
>To: fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org
>Sent: Thursday, October 19, 2006 11:22:01 PM
>Subject: FL: Undersuits
>
>
>I was looking through the FAQ, and found Sardog?s opinion on using a 
>unitard as an undersuit.  My first question is about material.  In the FAQ, 
>Sardog recommends cotton.  I do know that Cotton is an absorbent matieral.  
>Nylon and Polyester are not as absorbent.  (Nylon is what Under Armour uses 
>for Heat Gear shorts, and polyester for Heat Gear shirts.  I haven?t been 
>able to figure out why they use different materials for the shirt and 
>shorts.  Nor have I seen a polyester unitard anyway).  Is the absorptive 
>property of cotton something useful in the mascot/fursuit environment?
>Secondly, I was wondering if anyone had any experiences or opinions of a 
>unitard that has fingers and or a hood?
>Thanks

From cleverlilminx at yahoo.com  Sat Oct 21 19:45:27 2006
From: cleverlilminx at yahoo.com (Wendy Wassmer)
Date: Sat, 21 Oct 2006 16:45:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Undersuits (Furtech,
	if you're still monitoring this list... I'd value your opinions)

Hello everyone, I have had experience with Under Armor in another lining of costuming in a club called the 501st Legion.  A Star Wars costuming club.  I can say that normally after a "troop" or costumed event, everyone who was wearing UA (Under Armor) finds a pool of sweat in their Stormtrooper costumes, collecting in the plastic armor.  

Maybe another option could be silk?  I know that skiers wear long silk underwear under their ski suits to help wisk after sweat while they are sking.  Has anyone tried that route yet in a fursuit?


-Wendy

From furtech at akela.com  Sat Oct 21 22:52:14 2006
From: furtech at akela.com (Lance Ikegawa)
Date: Sat, 21 Oct 2006 19:52:14 -0700
Subject: FL: Undersuits (Furtech,
 if you're still monitoring this list... I'd value your opinions)
In-Reply-To: <20061021224725.12143.qmail@web51611.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20061021224725.12143.qmail@web51611.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <453ADCDE.3050302@akela.com>

A lot of the professional suit-performers (mascot, creature fx, etc.) 
have a routine they do that starts at least a day before they're going 
to be in costume.  This involved lots of hydrating (water, diluted 
gatorade, etc.)  and not taking long, hot showers (starting at least a 
day before).  Just take quick (like, 3 minute) cold showers.  If you 
take a hot shower (or soak in a bath or jacuzzi) on the day you're going 
to be in-costume, you will sweat like a pig.  Your skin can absorb (and 
then discharge) a LOT of water.

The type of undergarment will depend on the costume: with a 
loose-fitting mascot-style costume (with lots of air gaps) a nylon 
spandex unitard is best, since there is air for the moisture to 
evaporate away to.  As you move, this air is circulated in and out (you 
will often feel cooler walking easily than standing stock-still). 

For tight-fitting suits that do not breathe well (like many muscle-suits 
and Storm Trooper suits), cotton spandex is best.  You'll have to change 
it out more often (probably hourly), so bring a lot of extras because 
they'll get soaked.  I know some people who use those headbands that you 
soak in water in the summer and wear to keep cool, only they use them in 
reverse: they wear them dry and let them absorbe the water.  If you're 
REALLY desperate to not soak your suit, you can actually use disposeable 
diapers (or anything that will absorb water and store it)-- but I've 
never been that frantic.

There are exceptions: if you have an open-face costume or headless (like 
a "Cats" type costume), use nylon unitards.  Full head costumes create 
an enormous amount of heat and moisture build-up.  Without the head on, 
I can wear a full muscle suit covered in fur all day and only feel warm; 
put the head on and I'm starting to feel it in less than an hour.

Also, if there -is- air circulation use nylon spandex.  Inflateable 
costumes, costumes made with NFT fur and/or reticulated foam 
(open-celled foam) breathe enough to wick away the moisture faster than 
it can build up. 

I've not yet used the Under Armour line yet, so I'm not sure how 
effective it is (or not).  I use standard Baltog nylon or cotton spandex 
unitards for just about everything.  Even though nylon does send the 
moisture through, any covering will help to prevent the nasty elements 
of sweat from mucking up your costume.  I also thoroughly douse the 
costume (often turning it inside-out) with Endbac II.  Sometimes a 
quarter of a can on one costume and head.  The stink is from bacteria in 
your sweat and on your skin: if you destroy the bacteria, the costume 
won't stink.  My partner-in-crime learned this when she was doing 
maintenance on the Ripper costumes in "Tank Girl": they were shooting in 
a copper mine in Tuscon in high summer (110+ temps) all day.  When they 
missed -one- costume-- boy did they know it!  Whew!

Speaking of hygene, being well-scrubbed and not stinky -before- getting 
into your costume will go a long way to keeping it clean and 
stink-free.  As I said above, though: the day you're going to wear the 
costume (and the day before if you want to sweat even less), take quick 
cold showers (turn the water off during soaping) and you'll be clean and 
won't stink up your suit!

Lance

Sardog wrote:

>Hey All;
>
>I thought I'd update a note on this file...

>Me: Yes.

>SR: Don't recommend it... I'd recommend a cotton or similar material that will absorb the sweat, so that when they change, the bulk of the nastiness goes with the performer.
>
>This would be a good time for Furtech to chime in with his opinon.
>
>S.

>I've found some incredibly awesome fabric that is a supplex, and it's

>show is HIGHLY aerobic)  he can do two 45 minute sets and be sweating like

>>From: Sardog <sardognsca at yahoo.com>

>>To: fursuit-list at lists.fursuit.org
>>Subject: Re: FL: Undersuits
>>Date: Fri, 20 Oct 2006 04:10:17 -0700 (PDT)

>>Hey;
>>
>>I think the main reason for cotton, and, the absorbant nature of cotton is 
>>that it would retain the sweat your body gives off, as opposed to an 
>>underarmour type thing where the whole purpose is to transmit the sweat 
>>away from your body.
>>
>>So, why do we want it retain?  Well, one of the main reasons for wearing 
>>the suit is to aid in keeping the suits clean.  So... You sweat, it 
>>transfers to the cotton undersuit, you wash the undersuit.
>>
>>Also, at the time that I wrote that, I don't believe that underarmor was a 
>>significant player in the market, if they existed at all.  I can say that 
>>we are currently evaluating the use of UA and it's alternatives, as an 
>>option for undersuits.
>>
>>I would avoid the use of a suit with built in hands.  Your hands seem to be 
>>a major cooling point. Plus, it could affect your dexterity for doing up 
>>zippers, etc.
>>
>>As for the hoods..  I can only recommend them, although most of our people 
>>don't wear them.  (Yet complain bitterly when the long hair gets in their 
>>eyes) If nothing else, it helps stabilize their hair.  However, again, 
>>creates an effective barrier between their body and the suit.
>>
>>S.

From mljalpena at yahoo.com  Sun Oct 22 01:26:51 2006
From: mljalpena at yahoo.com (Mike Johnson)
Date: Sat, 21 Oct 2006 22:26:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
In-Reply-To: <20061015212035.GA7065@foxpup.forest.thefoxden.com>
Message-ID: <20061022052651.49128.qmail@web52010.mail.yahoo.com>

Here is some snippits of a message I was forwarded
from the MFF Programming Director, Chouette, which
sheds some light on the reason behind why the Fursuit
Parade isn't allowed in the Dealer's Den.  And even I
overlooked this fact myself...

Wildfox
MFF Constructed Fuzziness - Puppet Track
MFF FVS 2nd

"However, The Dealers Room does NOT want the whole
parade going through -- yes, (a) too many people, (2) 
too narrow aisles (they are packed to the gills to fit
in as many dealers as they can in the same
un-expanded-size room as last year), and (3) the
dealers did complain in the past.   Look, Anthrocon
has an absolutely HUMONGOUS room for the Dealers, so
the parade can easily go through there and works out
just fine.  
BUT  ---  OUR room is miniscule by comparison -- and
is already WAY overcrowded with dealer tables   Hence,
the Dealer Room's refusal to allow it in the parade
route for as long as their room remains this small.  
(Maybe at newer, bigger hotel, it will be different.
Most likely.)"

"And Make the route LONGER, by all means!   Make it
last as long as you can!  
It NEEDS to be made into more of a "spotlight" special
event.  It has needed this for years, as far as I'm
concerned.
---- Go out around the side of the hotel and back in,
if you want.  
[The only objections I heard or even echoed myself,
was that (a) no sidewalks out there, just grass or
walking in the street -- and there's not much audience
out there? ]
-- but hey DO it if it helps make it more of a parade
for you all??  All OK with me.
I keep suggesting to maybe walk the whole parade route
TWICE, to make it last longer?  You could shift the
route slightly for appearance's sake on the 2nd lap,
but .. hey, whatever works to make it longer event and
more of a Real Parade."

"Like I said, I haven't been able to read the posts,
but I can imagine what they're upset about -- and I
bet I would agree with most of it."  

"But we do need to compromise by giving the Dealers
Room want they DON'T want -- which is 120+ suiters
squeezing through their narrow over-crowded room.  1
or 2 suiters can wend their way through and shop, yes,
that's not a problem.
-- but a huge line of them is just more than they can
deal with and I can understand that."

1.  Overflow Hotel Online Reservation System Up and Operational
2.  Badge Art Submission Deadline
3.  Conbook Submission Deadline Fast Approaching
4.  Artshow Sold Out
5.  Preliminary Schedule Now Online
6.  Further Confusion 2007 announces Special Musical Guest

1.  Overflow Hotel Online Reservation System Up and Operational

The San Jose Doubletree is completely sold out at this point. However, we
have been able to obtain an overflow hotel for those of you who need the
rooms. Online registration is available as well as by telephone. The
Holiday Inn San Jose is within easy walking distance from the Doubletree
and has the amenities we want our attendees to have to make their stay
pleasant.

The price is $114 per night for up to 4 people, and rooms are available
for all convention days. Yes, this is more than the DoubleTree, but
extremely cheap for the Bay Area.

Please see the Further Confusion web site Hotel page for instructions on
how to reserve your room, and information on the Hotel Amenities, at the
link below.

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/hotel.php> 


2.  Badge Art Submission Deadline

Further Confusion is currently seeking artwork submissions for the 2007
membership badge inserts. Both color and black and white artwork will be
accepted, and all artwork will be considered on overall 'look and
feel', plus these additional points:

. Size: Art must scale to be printed at 4" x 2".
. Theme: Art must accurately reflect the theme of the con.
. Age appropriateness: The art must be suitable for viewing by children.

Artists submitting images should be aware that there is no payment for
badge art chosen, and the artist gives Further Confusion the right to
reproduce the image as badge art for FC2007. The artist will be credited
on the insert and in the con program book. The artist retains all other
copyrights and reproduction rights beyond the above.

Submission deadline is November 1st, 2006. All qualifying submissions will
be seriously considered and we will choose 6 designs. All artists will be
notified by December 1st as to whether or not their submissions have been
chosen.

For more information, please see:
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/badgeart.php> 


3.  Conbook Submission Deadline Fast Approaching

Our conbook submissions guidelines are now up and available. Remember, our
book is once again all color this year, so we can accept color as well as
black and white submission. The deadline for submitting art or written
materials is November 1, 2006. We also have room for a couple of short
stories and other written materials. For all the info please see the
following:

<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/conbook_guidelines.php>


4.  Artshow Sold Out

As of now, the Artshow for FC2007 is sold out. We expect that
applications currently in the mail will fill in the remaining panels.
While we're excited that our show has filled in record time, we're also
sad that some artists will miss out. We'll do our best to have as many of
you in the show as possible.

If you'd like to be put on a waiting list, please send in your application
as usual and we'll inform you if you have guaranteed space, or if you're
on the waiting list. We won't bank any cheques until we can guarantee you
space. It is usual that some artists cancel, or reduce their panel numbers
leading up to the con, so don't give up hope just yet. Also, it's common
that unused panels become available at show, so even if we can't guarantee
you panels, you may want to plan to bring along a half or full panel's
worth of artwork "just in case". Tell us if you're doing this, so we can
keep you informed, and prepare our databases before the show. 


5.  Preliminary Schedule Now Online

A preleminary version of the schedule for Further Confusion 2007 is now
online at our WWW site, available at
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/schedulebyday.php>!  This schedule
is connected directly into our scheduling system, so is subject to change
as we work on putting the year's convention together.  So, take a peek,
see what we have to offer now, and check back in the next few months as we
give you even more reason to make it out to San Jose, next January.


6.  Further Confusion 2007 announces Special Musical Guest

FC2007 is pleased to announce special music guests, Sub-level 03.  The
air will be buzzing with fresh energy and sounds as Sub-level 03 takes the
stage before you very ears.  Get your paws moving to the groove of SL3 in
fursuit or out and come party with SL3 on their Fallout tour show at
FC2007. 

<http://www.sublevel3.us/>


7.  Dealers Room Announcement

In November, we will be selecting at random people from the Dealer's Room
waiting list to be offered 12 half-table spaces for FC2007. In order to
be included in the selection, you should have your waiting list form sent
in by November 1st, 2006.  Please allow sufficient time for the USPS to
deliver it to us by that date. This will be the second round of random
drawing from the waiting list.  Those randomly chosen from the list will
be notified before the end of November.  If there is any space still
remaining after the second round is finished, it will be offered to people
on the waiting list by random drawing prior to the convention as and when
space becomes available.

Application forms for space in the Dealer's Room and Furry Marketplace, as
well as rules governing each area, can be found at:
 
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/dealers.php>. 

Please e-mail dealers at furtherconfusion.org if you have any questions. 


8.  Furry Marketplace Announcement

Furry Market Place Space Sales Round 2 About To Begin!

Starting November 1st, 2006, Further Confusion will be accepting
applications for purchase of 10 more spaces in our Furry Market Place
outside the main dealers room.

These spaces are available on a first come, first served basis. However,
we will not accept any forms postmarked prior to November 1st, 2006. If
you wish to apply for a space, download the form from this link below,
print it out, fill it out, write out your check for US $65.00 to Further
Confusion, and drop it in the mail on or after November 1st, 2006.

We will accept the first ten (10) purchases, based on the postmark on the
envelope. After those 10 are gone, this round of sales will close. Any
further applications and their checks will be returned to the owner,
uncashed.

Please note only one Furry Market Place space per person. Those that have
already purchased a space in Round One may not purchase another in this
round. The price for the space includes one full membership to the
convention.

If there are any spaces remaining when the Furry Market Place space opens
for vendor setup on Friday January 19th 2007 at 8:00am, those remaining
spaces will be offered for cash sale on a first come, first served basis
to qualified vendors on site. (Qualified means that the vendor must have a
California Sales Permit ID from the California State Board of Equalization
and be 18 years of age or older.)

The Round 2 Furry Market Place Form can be found at
<http://www.furtherconfusion.org/fc2007/pdfs/2007_FMPSignup_Round2.pdf>

Please e-mail dealers at furtherconfusion.org if you have any questions.


9.  FCTV Final Request for Contributions

Its that time of year again. Have some nifty furry video or show you'd
like to see on FCTV? Well now's the time to start the submittal process!

Right now anything with a PG or lower rating is on the table, so submit
away! Any length, any format. To submit, just send an e-mail to
fctv at furtherconfusion.org with information on your submission and we'll
take it from there! Also feel free to e-mail if there's something you
yourself didn't make, but would like to see on FCTV! We'll reach out to
content creators ourselves if we have to! 

Deadlines for major content submission is November 31st, so if you've got
that great video idea, get filming! 


10. Events Announcements

Do we have Species Panels for FC2007?

We have the usual suspects:  canids, dragons & scalies, felines, foxes,
marsupials, minotaurs and more, mustelids, rodents, ungulates, and wolves.
New offerings include aquatic furs, avians, and hyenas (which may be a new
aspect for canids).

Of unique interest are:
A panel on Kzinti by our GOH Jerry Pournelle and Matthew Joseph
Harrington: "A trenchcoat is probably not going to fool the enemy during a
war between different species. How was espionage conducted during the
Man-Kzin Wars?  Dr. Jerry E. Pournelle, Ph.D., computing expert and author
of The Children's Hour, and Matthew Joseph Harrington, author of Teacher's
Pet, have given examples in their work, and invite discussion."

And one for hybrids:
The Hybrid Panel summons you! If you are tired of panels for those "plain"
species,this is the place for you! Are you a cross breed of something fun
like a Wolf and a Tiger? Are you a mixture of something outragous like a
Dragon and a Penguin? Or maybe your something just plain weird,such as a
Spider-Hippo!
Whether you were created from evil expirements,Genetic DNA splicing, or
popped out of no where, this is the place to meet other like you in ways
never thought possible! Come see people and species never seen! All are
welcome, Hybrids and friends alike!

Some panels would still very much like additional panelists:
aquatic furs, bears & pandas or hyenas, hybrid furs, ungulates, and
wolves.  Rescue, Recovery, habitat, biology knowledge and/or any kind of
fan, literature, art, etc. knowledge are welcome.  Seize the opportunity
to show off what you know and love!

your parking slip in the meeting.

From eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com  Sun Oct 22 20:59:46 2006
From: eagleye1234555 at yahoo.com (Jason Taipale)
Date: Sun, 22 Oct 2006 17:59:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: FL: Undersuits
In-Reply-To: <453ADCDE.3050302@akela.com>
Message-ID: <20061023005946.67987.qmail@web52513.mail.yahoo.com>

  Is there really a difference in the cooling effect between nylon and cotton?  I know that nylon won?t absorb nearly as much water as cotton, but in the case of cotton, isn?t there still water there to cool?
   
  You?ve recommended cotton in a costume with bad airflow, and nylon in a costume with good airflow.  Does a mascot-style costume with regular fur (like you?d find a Jo Ann) have good airflow or bad airflow?  Would the fur fabric be able to dissipate the water, or would it collect there?  Would I be correct in assuming that a cotton style hood is better in a mascot style costume, as there would not be a lot of airflow in the head?
    One thing I don?t understand is why the Under Armour shirts are made of polyester instead of nylon.  Fleece material is polyester, and fairly warm too.  Perhaps the polyester fabric is softer?
   
  Thank you for the advice.


Lance Ikegawa <furtech at akela.com> wrote: A lot of the professional suit-performers (mascot, creature fx, etc.) 
have a routine they do that starts at least a day before they're going 
to be in costume.  This involved lots of hydrating (water, diluted 
gatorade, etc.)  and not taking long, hot showers (starting at least a 
day before).  Just take quick (like, 3 minute) cold showers.  If you 
take a hot shower (or soak in a bath or jacuzzi) on the day you're going 
to be in-costume, you will sweat like a pig.  Your skin can absorb (and 
then discharge) a LOT of water.

The type of undergarment will depend on the costume: with a 
loose-fitting mascot-style costume (with lots of air gaps) a nylon 
spandex unitard is best, since there is air for the moisture to 
evaporate away to.  As you move, this air is circulated in and out (you 
will often feel cooler walking easily than standing stock-still). 

For tight-fitting suits that do not breathe well (like many muscle-suits 
and Storm Trooper suits), cotton spandex is best.  You'll have to change 
it out more often (probably hourly), so bring a lot of extras because 
they'll get soaked.  I know some people who use those headbands that you 
soak in water in the summer and wear to keep cool, only they use them in 
reverse: they wear them dry and let them absorbe the water.  If you're 
REALLY desperate to not soak your suit, you can actually use disposeable 
diapers (or anything that will absorb water and store it)-- but I've 
never been that frantic.

There are exceptions: if you have an open-face costume or headless (like 
a "Cats" type costume), use nylon unitards.  Full head costumes create 
an enormous amount of heat and moisture build-up.  Without the head on, 
I can wear a full muscle suit covered in fur all day and only feel warm; 
put the head on and I'm starting to feel it in less than an hour.

Also, if there -is- air circulation use nylon spandex.  Inflateable 
costumes, costumes made with NFT fur and/or reticulated foam 
(open-celled foam) breathe enough to wick away the moisture faster than 
it can build up. 

I've not yet used the Under Armour line yet, so I'm not sure how 
effective it is (or not).  I use standard Baltog nylon or cotton spandex 
unitards for just about everything.  Even though nylon does send the 
moisture through, any covering will help to prevent the nasty elements 
of sweat from mucking up your costume.  I also thoroughly douse the 
costume (often turning it inside-out) with Endbac II.  Sometimes a 
quarter of a can on one costume and head.  The stink is from bacteria in 
your sweat and on your skin: if you destroy the bacteria, the costume 
won't stink.  My partner-in-crime learned this when she was doing 
maintenance on the Ripper costumes in "Tank Girl": they were shooting in 
a copper mine in Tuscon in high summer (110+ temps) all day.  When they 
missed -one- costume-- boy did they know it!  Whew!

Speaking of hygene, being well-scrubbed and not stinky -before- getting 
into your costume will go a long way to keeping it clean and 
stink-free.  As I said above, though: the day you're going to wear the 
costume (and the day before if you want to sweat even less), take quick 
cold showers (turn the water off during soaping) and you'll be clean and 
won't stink up your suit!

Lance

Sardog wrote:

From furtech at akela.com  Sun Oct 22 23:01:32 2006
From: furtech at akela.com (Lance Ikegawa)
Date: Sun, 22 Oct 2006 20:01:32 -0700
Subject: FL: Undersuits
In-Reply-To: <20061023005946.67987.qmail@web52513.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20061023005946.67987.qmail@web52513.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <453C308C.7000207@akela.com>

The difference is in what the material does with moisture: nylon spandex 
does not absorb water as fast as cotton spandex-- and much of the water 
it does absorb is transmitted through the material. Cotten will hold 
more water; nylon won't hold as much, keeping more sweat on your skin 
(and only passing some through). Neither has any real "cooling effect"; 
both are another layer of material that holds heat in. Both -do- move 
moisture (sweat) away from the body, helping to cool by evaporation. 
That's why a lot of suit-wearers don't wear unitards (just shorts and a 
t-shirt that they change out constantly). The more sweat you can get 
away from your skin, the cooler you will feel (evaporative cooling). 
Either material does help to filter the stinky stuff from getting to 
your suit.

With mascot-styled costumes (with regular fur) the best material depends 
on several points:
--How much do you sweat? If you sweat a lot, wear cotton. Change out 
when you feel soaked.
--How long will you be in costume? Long time (more than 20 minutes to 
one hour), wear nylon and suffer (but you won't have a wet-feeling 
costume-- ick)
--What kind of activity? If you're in a parade or dancing a rave, cotton 
will keep you cooler, but you will get soggy (no hugs! awful feeling!). 
If you can change out to other cotton clothing (even pajamas), you'll be 
cooler and have more endurance.

With mascot-styled suits and normal fake fur, you have room for more 
bulky under-clothing, so t-shirts and pajamas are great for this.

The nice thing about mascot-style suits is that you can also just go 
with shorts (with a bra if you're female): suits without foam-padding 
can be washed to get sweat and stink out after you use it. The reason a 
lot of professionals use t-shirts and shorts is that things like 
unitards are an extra layer of insulation, making the suit hotter. 
Liberal use of Endbac II after each wear should keep the suit from 
smelling for a weekend's con use (several hours of use a day). Wash and 
thoroughly dry (like, hang it in a dry, light place for a couple of 
days) before storing it or you'll get mildew (and that's almost 
-impossible- to get out!).

Tight-fitting suits often have foam padding: tougher to wash, so we 
suffer a little more to save on maintenance later. Tight-fitting suits 
without padding need 'em because otherwise the sweat directly goes onto 
the fur backing, making for gross, wet costumes.

Lance

Jason Taipale wrote:

>   
>  You?ve recommended cotton in a costume with bad airflow, and nylon in a costume with good airflow.  Does a mascot-style costume with regular fur (like you?d find a Jo Ann) have good airflow or bad airflow?  Would the fur fabric be able to dissipate the water, or would it collect there?  Would I be correct in assuming that a cotton style hood is better in a mascot style costume, as there would not be a lot of airflow in the head?
>    One thing I don?t understand is why the Under Armour shirts are made of polyester instead of nylon.  Fleece material is polyester, and fairly warm too.  Perhaps the polyester fabric is softer?
>   
>  Thank you for the advice.
>

>


From antimon at earthlink.net  Mon Oct 23 03:15:07 2006
From: antimon at earthlink.net (Antimon)
Date: Mon, 23 Oct 2006 03:15:07 -0400 (GMT-04:00)
Subject: FL: Undersuits
Message-ID: <27083999.1161587708215.JavaMail.root@elwamui-polski.atl.sa.earthlink.net>

I find the cooling effect comes from the wetness.  The (even warm) air hittign the wet unitard actually chills you even when in suit, any air movement has a chilling effect with a nylon/lycra blended skin, it's a nic ebenefit and makes for quicker recovers.  a dip into the headless lounge for 15-20 minutes soem water i'm good to go out again withtotu haveing to de suit.

The primary reasons though i wear an undersuit is 1) ro protect my suit (and thsoe huggign me) from my sweat, the only part of my suit that gets damp i s my butt which no one hugss anyway (udner the tail and small of my back) and the inside of my head.  and 2) to project my skin from the not so comfortable fur backing, it also makes teh suit easier to get on and of fit glides even when i'm soaked, try gettign a soaked fursuit off your bare skin.

but i do find i have better endurance and dotn feel as hot wearing it the material doesn't keep any heat in...it travels right through it, it i snot insulatign at all, in fact quite the opisette it conducts the heat away

From yggithalatyr at gmail.com  Mon Oct 23 04:06:23 2006
From: yggithalatyr at gmail.com (Ashford Wyrd)
Date: Mon, 23 Oct 2006 03:06:23 -0500
Subject: FL: Undersuits
In-Reply-To: <27083999.1161587708215.JavaMail.root@elwamui-polski.atl.sa.earthlink.net>
References: <27083999.1161587708215.JavaMail.root@elwamui-polski.atl.sa.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <be1fa94c0610230106w42f20eecu6ec643240be2d6c@mail.gmail.com>

in general, natural fibres (Cotton, linen, and wool) breathe better,
insulate better, and are more absorbent than synthetic fibres (nylon
and polyester). Silk, and her wood derived artificial sister, rayon,
have properties somewhere between natural and synthetic, though their
fibers are the strongest, and seem to be even stronger when wet.

What does this mean to a fursuiter?

If you want to stay cool, you will want to wear natural fibers under your suit.

Hi all,

Just a heads-up for you, from MFF's Programming Dept.:

MFF has a NEW special event planned for fursuiters
(and non-fursuiters) 
that starts right after Opening Ceremonies.
It's one of MFF's "County Fair" themed events.
If you want to participate, make sure you get there at
1PM on FRIDAY to 
SIGN UP!

Here's the info:

COUNTY FUR PAGEANT ?-- SIGN UP, ELIMINATION, &
REHEARSAL
Do you have the qualities the judges are (arbitrarily)
looking for in 
our 
MFF 2006 County Fur Pageant winner?  Is it Dignity?
Elegance? Charisma? 
Having perfected a ?royal wave?? Not having TP stuck
to your foot? ? 
Nobody 
knows, but our judges say they will know ?It? when
they find it.  Maybe 
YOU 
have what it takes!
ELIBIBILITY:  Open to ANY AGE, GENDER, or SPECIES
[fursuiters, humans, 
whatnots ? i.e., all attendees are eligible].
TO SIGN UP:   Arrive at 1 PM sharp on FRIDAY, and
compete to be in the 
actual Pageant, to follow.
After Sign-Up and some simple elimination rounds (just
talking and 
walking, 
no ?talent show? or anything complicated), the judges
will choose only 
30 
entrants to compete in the actual Pageant. 
Eliminations may go 
quickly, so 
arrive on time to participate.  The last part of this
event is reserved 
to 
"rehearse" the lucky 30 that are chosen to be in the
actual Pageant.
WARNING:  PG RATED behavior and appearance are
-mandatory- for 
participants.  This is an abbreviated furry version of
those clich?d 
county 
fair pageants, after all, so join the roleplay fun. 
Non-PG behavior 
will 
result in immediate elimination and loss of any
titles/prizes won.

COUNTY FUR PAGEANT!   [FIRST TIME EVER EVENT  . . .
possibly ANYWHERE]
Ever been to a County Fair ?beauty pageant??  Well,
this is our own 
warped 
Furry version, in abbreviated form ? and for us,
everyfur is 
beautiful.  From the previous Elimination event,
perhaps 30 contestants 
may 
make it into this Pageant.  On our runway, there will
be music and 
strutting galore!  There?s no time for a talent
competition, but 
undoubtedly there will be ?hamming it up? involved.
Nobody really knows 
what the judges will be looking for, but they say
they?ll know ?It? 
when 
they see it.  Our Judges will select 3 finalists, and
then pick ONE to 
be 
our Midwest FurFest 2006 COUNTY FUR PAGEANT Winner. 
Our County Fur 
Pageant 
Winner and Runners-Up will be awarded prizes and will
be given some 
royal 
raiment (crown, sashes, etc.) that they can wear
during the weekend, 
and in 
the Fursuit Parade.  Of course, they won't be sitting
on a parade 
float, 
but the County Fur Pageant Winner and the Runners-Up
will march in the 
Fursuit Parade, in a ?place of honor?.

>for the breaking down of closed cell foam, we have been tidying one of
>our "prop graveyards" and I came across some closed cell foam that has
>been in direct sunlight for about 12 months (we only get about 350 days
>a year of sunlight), with little damage or brittleness.

>I have a couple materials - related questions I would like to ask:
>I am considering trying to build a head using the "Fun Foam" you can
>find in craft stores.  (I think this is polyethylene foam.)  However, I
>find that the foam has a fairly pungent odor.  Does anyone know what
>this odor is, is it toxic, and does the smell subside enough that it
>would be worth building a head?
>I know that the upholstery foam gradually changes from a white to a
>brownish yellow.  I have seen the foam degrade just by sitting in a
>dark
>closet, only exposed to the air.  Does anyone know approximately how
>long the foam lasts, or if there are ways to slow the decay down?  I
>wonder if adding a layer of fabric, like maybe some inexpensive cotton
>fabric, would work?

From rsg0910 at iglou.com  Fri Oct 27 20:30:55 2006
From: rsg0910 at iglou.com (Robert Goodwin)
Date: Fri, 27 Oct 2006 20:30:55 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: FL: Matierals Questions
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "rufus wolf" at Oct 27, 2006 07:23:01 PM
Message-ID: <E1Gdc6B-0001G3-Rj@shell1.iglou.com>

> Well carpet might not be the answer. I know some people swear by it,but how 
> about some old rubber welcome mats?? its rubber and made to be walked on.

Have you seen those 'puzzle mat' kind of things? That is, the outer edges 
of the mats fit the other mats perfectly, forming a walking area, another 
larger square, that kind of thing? They may be a bit thick, but they're 
great for walking. You can use slippers, flipflops, or sandals as well.

I've seen them out at the local membership warehouses as well as some 
hardware stores and maybe some discount stores in black and colored. If 
I'm counting right, they're in packs of 4-6, up to an inch thickness.

I know a counselor who has her initials in them on her wall, the smaller 
kind that you pull put the letters and replace them.

Gotta agree with what Karen D and Simon S say about carpet. I wouldn't 
even consider using it for feet for those reasons.

More suggestions can be found in the fursuit FAQ/Wiki.

(...wiping off some highlighter off his monitor after going from books to 
notes to computer...)

-boogi-

----- Original Message ----
From: J.T. Beckett <>
To: sardognsca at yahoo.com
Sent: Saturday, October 21, 2006 12:24:26 PM
Subject: Re: FL: Undersuits


I've found some incredibly awesome fabric that is a supplex, and it's 
completely waterproof... yet comfortable like cotton, and strechy like 
spandex.  My hubby wears it for his performances (not in suit... but his 
show is HIGHLY aerobic)  he can do two 45 minute sets and be sweating like 
crazy under the shirt, but there's not a drop of sweat to be seen on the 
outside of the shirt.

From dlely at juno.com  Wed Nov  1 23:08:04 2006
From: dlely at juno.com (David L. Ely)
Date: Wed, 1 Nov 2006 20:08:04 -0800
Subject: FL: Fursuiting Event: Pasadena (CA) Doo Dah Parade
Message-ID: <20061101.201003.-348997.3.dlely@juno.com>

Hello Fellow Fursuiters and Furiends:

It's that time of the year for . . .

. . . the 30th Occational Pasadena Doo Dah Parade on Sunday the 19th of
November (that's the weekend before Thanksgiving)!  If you've got a
fursuit, if you wanna show off, if you didn't suit up on Halloween, if
you wanna be wacky, or even if you just wanna hang with (and maybe help)
a bunch of furries/scalies/featheries . . . then YOU are invited to walk,
march, skip, hop, gallop, skate, bike, pogo stick, or unicycle with the
"Coast to Coast Critters" fursuit brigade!

Here's how to participate: 1) simply e-mail me at dlely at juno.com telling
me you'll be there.  2) Check out the Parade's official web site at
http://www.pasadenadoodahparade.info/ for further information and maps. 
Then on Sunday the 19th of November: 3) meet me and all of the other
participants in Memorial Park (85 East Holly Street in Pasadena CA 91103)
before 10:30 AM.  4) Pay your $10.00 per person entry fee to the
organizers (The Light Bringer Project, a nonprofit arts organization). 
5) Wait in the park and have some fun . . . then jump in the Parade at
11:30 AM and have more fun!

But wait there's more!  After the parade everyfur usually chows down at a
popular Pasadena watering hole!

If you have any questions, feel free to e-mail me.  Hope to see ya all
there!

David L. Ely - AKA: Scruff E. Coyote - dlely at juno.com
"How many hearts with warm blood in them are beating
under the cover of the woods . . . .   A multitude of
animal people, intimately related to us . . . are busy
about their own affairs as we are about ours." - John Muir

From karen.upfront at shaw.ca  Tue Nov  7 09:40:17 2006
From: karen.upfront at shaw.ca (Karen Dollmont)
Date: Tue, 07 Nov 2006 07:40:17 -0700
Subject: FL: furing breasts
References: <c9e.228c6bf.328131da@aol.com>
Message-ID: <005801c7027a$a55f4b60$6701a8c0@karen>

If you have a walking foot machine it shouldn't show seams, if not use a seam ripper to pull the fur through the seams. We also use a wire BBQ brush to brush out seams and it works great.. good luck. 
Karen Up Front Mascots
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Tripncheata at aol.com

From camstone at dirtdeninn.com  Wed Nov  8 08:23:56 2006
From: camstone at dirtdeninn.com (camstone)
Date: Wed, 08 Nov 2006 08:23:56 -0500
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
In-Reply-To: <BA97EF5E-2A3A-443B-8730-787B3CE7D962@bright.net>
References: <101720061607.8849.4534FFA7000201F70000229122068246939801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>
	<45353EBC.6030001@gmx.net>	<F1D381FA-A746-4169-8728-75FE64410BB9@bright.net>
	<B2ABDCEF-78A2-4F6B-AD5F-196C857422B2@thefoxden.com>
	<BA97EF5E-2A3A-443B-8730-787B3CE7D962@bright.net>
Message-ID: <4551DA6C.3090004@dirtdeninn.com>

Couple of minor points regarding the fursuit parade...

Are the aisles wide enough for fursuiters to pass "cleanly?" - and do we
know if anyone had anything broken or damaged when the fursuit went
through the dealers room?

>>not really, when AC was at 500 attendees, parade was like 50.  the
>>year we had 1100 attendees, we broke 100, this year, 2000 broke 200.
>>    
>>
Yep, most cons follow the 10% rule, some more, some less. Depends
greatly on the makeup of the attendees and whether there is a strong
fursuiting programming track or not. The availability of less expensive
suits (mass produced <$500) and partials are also making it a little
easier to get "in on the fun." But unfortunately, AC this year didn't
break "officially" break 200, as we were 197 strong as I recall the
dorsai's count.

Cheers,
    Camstone


From mljalpena at yahoo.com  Wed Nov  8 16:48:48 2006
From: mljalpena at yahoo.com (Mike Johnson)
Date: Wed, 8 Nov 2006 13:48:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: FL: Opinions..  Fursuit Parades.
In-Reply-To: <4551DA6C.3090004@dirtdeninn.com>
Message-ID: <20061108214848.51156.qmail@web52015.mail.yahoo.com>

The aisles are unfourtunately not wide enough for a
whole parade.  If a couple fursuiters at a time pass
through, there isn't too big of a deal but if 150+ in
a parade pass through, it's going to jam the aisles
and block customers...and keep dealers from making $$$
(which aparently some dealers can't spare for a few
minutes).

We have a compromise with the Dealer's Den though
where the route of the parade will be posted in there
on the day of the parade and, if the dealers choose
that they want to see it, they'll temporarly shut down
for a few minutes to go view the parade.

It's the best we can do until we get into a newer
hotel.

Wildfox
MFF Constructed Fuzziness - Puppet

From santafox at comcast.net  Thu Nov  9 13:55:15 2006
From: santafox at comcast.net (Santa Fox)
Date: Thu, 09 Nov 2006 18:55:15 +0000
Subject: FL: MFF Fursuit Track: Last Minute Schedule Addition: Kinetic
	Fursuits
Message-ID: <110920061855.4432.45537993000663E50000115022064246139801000E9B020E9C@comcast.net>

My appologies for putting this into the mailboxes of anyone not attending MFF - there isn't a list specifically for MFF fursuiters, and I wanted to get this out where as many suiters attending MFF as possible will see it.

Due to technical difficulties, there was a last-minute fursuit track panel addition to the MFF schedule that didn't fully make it into all schedule-related publications, so I want to let everyone know what this panel is about. There's also an important time and location change for this panel: it is going to be at 2 PM on Sunday in Arlington Heights.

Kinetic Fursuits is a panel I am hosting on how to design fursuits to allow for more realistic creature-like movements and body shaping. As an avid professional puppeteer and fursuiter, I routinely incorporate puppetry design concepts into my unique personal fursuits, creating characters that can do things not possible in more typical fursuit designs. The goal of this panel is to let others get an inside look at how my designs work while helping to answer a question I commonly hear: "How does he do that?" This is a fursuit construction panel touching a little on performance, but anyone (non-suiters, too) who's curious about my unique fursuit characters is invited to come and learn more about them.

Once again, this panel has been moved in order to allow MFF's fursuit building furs the chance to attend both Fursuit Construction 2 and Kinetic Fursuits. The Kinetic Fursuits' panel will be at 2 PM on Sunday in Arlington Heights, immediately following the Advanced Fursuit Performance panel.

Cheers,
Santa Fox

P.S. If you're curious about my creations, just visit my website listed below :-)
--
Santa Fox's Den - http://santafox.home.comcast.net/

From dlely at juno.com  Fri Nov 17 01:27:57 2006

Dear Parade Loving Furs and Fursuiters:

Just a reminder, this coming Sunday the 19th is the 30th Occasional
Annual Pasadena Doo Dah Parade in southern California and yer all invited
to watch, help, or if ya have a fursuit, participate!

For additional information or to RSVP e-mail me at: dlely at juno.com.  For
parade information go to: http://www.pasadenadoodahparade.info.

tortillas...
